_data.title: 24 Character Strengths
_data.description: Know more about these strengths
_data.author: nanc

cards.q: What do we mean by the **Creativity** strength
cards.a: It is the coming up with new & productive ways to think and do things

cards.q: What do we mean by the **Curiosity** strength
cards.a: It is taking an interest in experience for its own sake, and finding things/ knowledge fascinating

cards.q: What do we mean by **Judgement and Open-mindedness**
cards.a: It is examining things from all sides, listening to all and not jumping to conclusions

cards.q: What do we mean by having a **Love of Learning**
cards.a: It is mastering new skills or topics on one’s own or in school

cards.q: What is having a **Perspective** strength
cards.a: It is being able to provide good advice to others

cards.q: What do we mean by **Bravery** strength
cards.a: It is not running from threat, challenge or pain, and speaking up for what is right

cards.q: What is **Perseverence or Grit**
cards.a: It is finishing what one starts, and completing something despite obstacles

cards.q: What do we mean by **Honesty**
cards.a: It is speaking the truth and presenting oneself sincerely and genuinely

cards.q: What do we mean by having **Zest**
cards.a: It is approaching and leading life with excitement & energy - feeling alive and active

cards.q: What do we mean by the strength of **Love**
cards.a: It is valuing close relationships with others, and being close to people

cards.q: What do we mean by the strength of **Kindness**
cards.a: It is doing favors and good deeds for others, and helping them, and taking care of them

cards.q: What do we mean by **Social Intelligence** strength
cards.a: It is being aware of motives and feelings of other people and oneself

cards.q: What do we mean by **Team work**
cards.a: It is working well as a member of a group or team - being loyal to the group

cards.q: What do we mean by **Fairness**
cards.a: It is treating all people the same; giving everyone a fair chance

cards.q: What do we mean by **Leadership**
cards.a: It is to encourage a group of valued members to accomplish tasks

cards.q: What do we mean by the strength of **Forgiveness**
cards.a: It is forgiving those who have done wrong and accepting people’s shortcomings

cards.q: What do we mean by the **Humility** strength
cards.a: It is letting one's victories speak for themselves and not seeking the spotlights

cards.q: What do we mean by the strength of **Prudence**
cards.a: It is being careful of one's choices and not taking undue risks

cards.q: What do we mean by the strength of **Self Regulation**
cards.a: It is regulating what one feels and does - being disciplined

cards.q: What is **Appreciation**
cards.a: It is noticing & appreciating all kinds of beauty and excellence

cards.q: What is the strength of **Gratitude**
cards.a: It is being aware and thankful for the all the good things that happen

cards.q: What do we mean by the strength of **Hope / Optimism**
cards.a: It is expecting the best in the future and working to achieve it

cards.q: What is the strength of **Humour**
cards.a: It is liking to laugh & tease; bringing smiles to other people; seeing a light side of things

cards.q: What do we mean by the strength of **Religiousness & Spirituality**
cards.a: It is having beliefs about the higher purpose and meaning of the Universe

_data.title: About KNO
_data.description: All information about the KNO.cards platform
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is KNO.cards
cards.a: A platform that holds a library of decks on different topics

cards.q: What does the deck hold
Are the decks on a particular subject or few subjects only
cards.a: No. They are and can be on different subjects that are of likely interest to the visitors of this library.

cards.q: Is it like Wikipedia
Does that mean the KNO decks will not have depth
What topics are covered in the General Series
cards.a: These give information on a topic of universal appeal within a subject

cards.q: What topics are covered in the Professional Series
cards.a: These have topics more suited for someone connected to the respective field

cards.q: In what way is KNO different from other information websites
cards.a:
1. One, it is **topical** providing a way for a learner to update herself / himself
2. It follows the flashcards format for a more **natural and engaging** experience
3. It is **easily viewable** and **conveniently sharable** between friends

cards.q: How often will topics get added to KNO
cards.a: On a daily basis

cards.q: Who creates the content of the decks
cards.a: The KNO team. Folks who have an interest in an area and keep abreast of the latest happenings on different subjects.

cards.q: How do you ensure that the information is correct and upto date
So what are the terms for accessing the decks
cards.a: The information is provided on a **as-is basis**.

cards.q: Is there any registration or login required to access the decks
cards.a: No

cards.q: How do we flip a card
cards.a:
- On mobiles, swipe left to flip forward and swipe right to reverse flip
- On desktops, click or tap on the right part of the card to flip forward and tap on the left part to reverse flip

cards.q: Is there a way to install KNO as an App
cards.a: Yes. KNO is a **Progressive Web App** (PWA). You can add it to your Home Screen when you visit the home page (https://kno.cards).

cards.q: How to add KNO as an app in Android devices
cards.a: On Android devices, you will notice a prompt of **Add to Home Screen** appearing when you visit the home page. Tapping on it, adds the KNO icon to the *app tray*

cards.q: How to add KNO as an app in iOS devices
cards.a: On iOS devices, after loading the home page, tap on **Share >> Add to Home Screen** and follow the instructions that follow.

cards.q: What information of the user is being captured while they access a deck
cards.a: The platform uses Google Analytics to get statistics of usage. This is meant to provide the team with information on which decks are more popularly accessed and help improve the usefulness of KNO.

cards.q: What should I do if the information mentioned in the deck has errors
Is there a way to suggest a topic that is not available in the KNO library
cards.a: Yes, in the Home page, there is a *suggestion* icon which lets you share a topic of interest. Once we receive your suggestion, we will assign it to an internal expert who will put together relevant content and post a deck.

cards.q: For other matters, is there a way to reach the KNO team
cards.a: Email us on: **connect2rmr@gmail.com**

_data.title: 4th Industrial Revolution
_data.description: Know more about this edition
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the 4th Industrial Revolution mean
cards.a: Simply put, **4IR** is a combination of humans and machines in the workplace

cards.q: What were the earlier three Industrial Revolutions
cards.a:
1. **First Revolution** was Mechanisation
2. **Second Revolution** was Electrification
3. **Third Revolution** was Automation and Globalisation

cards.q: Who first spoke of the Fourth Industrial Revolution
cards.a: **Professor Klaus Schwab**, founder and executive chairman of the World Economic Forum described it in his book, *The Fourth Industrial Revolution* in 2016

cards.q: How did the term: **Industrial Revolutions** come about
cards.a: The noted 19th century economic historian **Arnold Toynbee** mentioned it while describing British economic development between 1760 to 1840

cards.q: In what way is 4IR different from 3IR
cards.a: There has been rapid changes to process and societal patterns caused by interconnectivity and smart automation

cards.q: What and when was the 1st Industrial Revolution
cards.a: It was a transition from **hand production** methods to **machine production** using steam power. The period was between **1760 to 1840**

cards.q: What and when was the 2nd Industrial Revolution
cards.a: It was called the *Technological* revolution and marked by **railroad and telegraph networks**. The period was between 1871 and 1914

cards.q: What and when was the 3rd Industrial Revolution
cards.a: It was called the *Digital* revolution and marked by **computer and communication technology**. The period was after World War II

cards.q: What are the characteristics of 4IR
cards.a:
It is characterized by a fusion of technologies that is blurring the lines between the physical, digital, and biological spheres
1. **Interconnection** between machines and sensors (IoTs)
2. **Information Transparency** letting organisations take decisions based on data
3. **Technical Assistance** offered by computing systems to aid human decisions
4. **Decentralised Decisions** taken by automated systems based on data available

cards.q: What are some of the components of 4IR
cards.a:
- mobile devices
- IoTs
- smart sensors
- big data analytics
- on-demand computer resources

cards.q: What is distinctive about 4IR in comparison to earier revolutions
cards.a: The speed of breakthroughs being witnessed is unpreceded in history

cards.q: What are some of these breakthroughs
cards.a:
- Artificial Intelligence / Robotics
- The Internet of Things / Autonomous Vehicles
- Nanotechnology / Biotechnology
- Materials Science / Energy Storage
- 3D Printing / Quantum Computing

cards.q: What are some of the challenges 4IR brought along
cards.a:
1. Privacy concerns
2. *Big Brother is watching* concerns 
3. People have to adapt to new skill sets (*else become unemployable*)
4. Lack of regulation leading to unclear legal issues

_data.title: Air Quality Database: 2022 report
_data.description: A summary of the report
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: Who compiles the Air Quality Report
cards.a: **WHO**: World Health Organisation

cards.q: What is the aim of the Air Quality Report published by WHO
cards.a:
1. To **measure air quality** to determine population exposure to air pollution
2. To **raise awareness** of air pollution and its impact on health
3. To provide **a snapshot** of air quality across countries

cards.q: What are the measurement parameters of air quality
cards.a:
1. Annual mean concentrations of **nitrogen dioxide** (NO₂)
2. **Particulate matter** of a diameter equal or smaller than 10 *μm* (PM₁₀) or equal or smaller than 2.5 *μm* (PM₂.₅)

cards.q: How many cities did the report cover
cards.a: **6000** cities in **117** countries

cards.q: How often is the report generated
cards.a: Once every **2-3** years

cards.q: What are the key findings of the 2022 report
cards.a:
1. That **most cities exceed** the maximum recommended air quality guideline levels
2. Only a **few cities** in the high income countries meet the guidelines
3. More than **half of the urban population** lives in cities with over **6 times** the guideline levels

cards.q: From the cities measured how many meet the air quality guidelines
cards.a:
1. About **17%** and most of them from the high income countries
2. From the low or medium income less than **1%** of cities meet the guidelines

cards.q: What are WHOs global air quality guidelines
cards.a:
They recommended **maximum annual mean levels** of:
- **15** *µg*/m3 for PM₁₀
- **5** *µg*/m3 for PM₂.₅ 
- **10** µg/m3 for NO₂

cards.q: What is Particulate Matter
cards.a:
It is a complex mixture of solid and liquid particles suspended in the air such as:
- sulfate
- nitrates
- aerosols
- sea salt
- black carbon
- mineral dust

cards.q: What are the sources of Particulate Matter
cards.a:
- Residential fuel burning
- Transport
- Power plants
- Agriculture
- Waste burning

cards.q: What are the health impacts of Particulate Matter
cards.a:
1. These particles can penetrate and lodge deep inside the lungs
2. The smaller particles can penetrate the lung barrier and enter the blood system
3. Chronic exposure causes cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, as well as lung cancer

cards.q: Which is the most polluted city in the world
cards.a: The report **does not rank cities** on air pollution

cards.q: What are the suggestions from the report
cards.a:
1. To **monitor** air quality regularly
2. Support use of **clean energy** for *cooking, heating and lighting*
3. Build **affordable public transport** including *cycle-friendly* networks
4. Invest in **energy efficient** power generation
5. Include air pollution in health workers **curricula**

cards.q: When is World Health Day celebrated
cards.a: 7 April each year

cards.q: What is the significance of that day
cards.a: It marks the anniversary of the founding of WHO in **1948**

_data.title: Bhailang: The toy programming language
_data.description: Know more about how this joke became a new language
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Bhai-Lang**
cards.a: In the words of its creators it is a new *toy programming language* developed in 2022

cards.q: Who developed this language
cards.a: Two Indian developers: **Rishabh Tripathi** and **Aniket Singh**

cards.q: Does the word Bhai have a meaning
cards.a: In hindi language *bhai* means **brother**

cards.q: Why did they create such a language
cards.a: It is rumoured that it began as a joke

cards.q: Does the choice of the name mean more than *brother*
cards.a: It seeks inspiration from *bhai-talk* (bro-talk)

cards.q: Is the language syntax similar to any existing language
What are the quirks of the Bhai-Lang
How does one write a **block of code**
cards.a:
1. One starts with: **hi bhai** (meaning **hi brother**)
2. And ends with **bye bhai** (meaning **bye brother**)
```
hi bhai
  bol bhai "Hello World";
bye bhai
```

cards.q: How do we assign a variable in Bhai-Lang
cards.a:
```
bhai ye hai a = 3;
```
This is equivalent to:
```
let a = 3;
```
> literally it means: *brother, this is a = 3*

cards.q: How do we print or *console.log* data
Does it support conditions
Does it support loops
cards.a:
Yes. It supports most of the constructs of any modern language such as:
- types
- loops
- conditionals
- built-ins

cards.q: Is there a website for more details
Any other interesting features
cards.a:
If the program runs successfully, the console displays:
```
Shandaar bhai 🎉
```
 
> literally meaning **great bro**

cards.q: How does it display a syntax error
cards.a:
```
❌ Arre Bhai Bhai Bhai !!!
```

cards.q: Does it have a future
cards.a: Wait and watch!

_data.title: Bionic Eyes
_data.description: Know more about how this technology can help semi-blind people
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is a **Bionic Eye**
cards.a: An electrical device that assists in restoring a **sense of vision** to the user

cards.q: Why do people require artificial eyes
How does a human see things using healthy eyes
cards.a:
1. An eye takes in *light* through the **pupil**
2. The lens, then, *focuses that light* onto the back of the eye, where there is a thick layer of light sensitive tissue called the **retina**
3. Cells called **photoreceptors** turn the light into *electrical signals* 
4. These signals travel down the **optic nerve** to the brain
5. The brain, then, interprets *interprets the images*.

cards.q: Which type of sight problems can the bionic eye solve
cards.a: People with vision loss like partial or color loss caused by genetics, illness or injury

cards.q: Can people see like others using bionic eyes
cards.a: No. While it cannot restore vision it helps people who are completely blind perceive light and reflections of light.

cards.q: What, then, is the use of bionic eyes
cards.a: Even though these artificial eyes cannot restore complete vision, it allows folks with impaired vision to become **more mobile and independent**, and return to them some of the *quality of life* they lost or did not have

cards.q: Can people who have never had eyesight benefit from bionic eyes
How does the Bionic eye work
cards.a: It consists of a **camera**, attached to a pair of glasses, which transmits *radio signals* to a **microchip implanted in the retina**. The implanted chip convert these signals into electrical impulses to stimulate cells in the retina that connect to the optic nerve.

cards.q: When did the research for bionic eye begin
When was the first bionic eye transplant done
What is the current state of bionic eyes

_data.title: Brain Machine Interface
_data.description: Know more about the advances in this field
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is a Brain-Machine Interface
cards.a: **BMI** is a device that **translates neuronal information** into *commands* capable of **controlling external software or hardware** such as a computer or robotic arm

cards.q: Is it the same as **Brain-Computer Interface**
cards.a: Yes, BMIs are also referred to as BCIs

cards.q: What are the uses of BMIs
cards.a: BMIs are often used as **assisted living devices** for individuals with *motor or sensory impairments*

cards.q: When did the research in this area begin
cards.a: In the 70s. But it wasn't till the 90s that some **neuroprosthetic** devices were implanted in humans.

cards.q: Will a BMI technology help a patient having paralysis
cards.a: Yes. One of its intent is to let such patients **regain independence** through the control of computers and mobiles e.g. *people with quadriplegia*.

cards.q: Why is it gaining prominence today
cards.a: Due to advances being made in **Speech synthesis** and **Artificial Intelligence**, one can provide a much *richer* and more *normal* life experience to such people

cards.q: What are the different senses that could potentially be *used* using BMI
cards.a:
The following areas of the brain could get *reactivated* using BMI:
1. **Visual Cortex**: that processes information from our eyes
2. **Auditory Cortex**: that process our perception and interpretation of sound
3. **Somatosensory Cortex**: that process our sense of touch
4. **Motor Cortex**: that executes our motor movements

cards.q: Can BMI be used to control, *say a mouse*, on a computer
cards.a: Yes. As users think of moving their arms, that thought can be **decoded** and sent to the computer to move a *virtual mouse*.

cards.q: Is not electroencephalogram (**EEG**) a BMI
cards.a: One can think of an **EEG** as a non-invasive BMI

cards.q: What is **Electrocorticography** (ECoG)
What is the difference between EEG and ECoG
cards.a: EEG is a **non-invasive** procedure while an ECoG is an **invasive** procedure

cards.q: What are **Neural Implants**
cards.a: They are **technological devices** that connect directly to a person's **brain**

cards.q: Where are they placed
cards.a: They are usually placed on the **surface** of the brain, or attached to the brain's **cortex**

cards.q: What purpose do neural implants serve
What are the components of a neural implant
cards.a:
1. It has small flexible *threads* to detect neural signals
2. It has a **battery** and charger that can be *wirelessly charged from the outside*

cards.q: How are these implants placed in the brain
cards.a: They are surgically placed using sophisticated **robotic system** that a neurosurgeon operates

cards.q: What are some of the challenges in development of the electrodes of these implants
cards.a: The electrodes must be as **small** and **flexible** as the surrounding neurons. Additionally, its material must be such that it is compatible with the surrounding tissues

cards.q: What are some of the challenges with the electronics of the implant
cards.a: The chip in the implant needs to convert the electric signals from the electrodes into neural information and amplify them to external devices. This needs to happen in real-time and must be possible using low-powered devices. This is a huge technological challenge.

cards.q: Are neural implants available today
cards.a: Experiments have been conducted and some implants have been made. However, it is not yet approved for wide use anywhere.

_data.title: Biometric Passport
_data.description: Know more about this new type of passport
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Biometric Passport**
cards.a: It is  is a *passport* that has an **embedded microprocessor RFID chip** which contains *biometric information* of the passport holder

cards.q: Is it the same as **e-passport**
cards.a: Yes, it is also referred to as **e-passport** or **digital passport**

cards.q: What is the information that is held inside the chip
cards.a:
Biometric information such as:
- fingerprints of all ten fingers
- iris scan
- color photograph of the face 
- digital signature

cards.q: What is a RFID chip
cards.a: RFID is Radio Frequency Identification. It is a radio wave technology to read data

cards.q: What are the advantages of a biometric passport
cards.a:
- **Faster entry** at border control
- **Secure identification**
- **Fraud prevention**
- **Protection of privacy**

cards.q: Does a biometric passport look different from a traditional passport
cards.a: No. But they have a **small gold camera** symbol at the bottom of the passport

cards.q: What is an **ePassport gate**
cards.a: Border Control (*Immigration*) in certain countries have a system where a traveller can place the passport at the gate and the system will check the data and confirm the identity of the traveller

cards.q: Is biometric passport compulsory for entry in any country
cards.a: No, but some countries require **e-passports** for certain categories of visa

cards.q: How is information of an e-passport protected
How does cryptographic signature help in preventing access to data by unauthorised users
cards.a: This technology calls for a special **key** (digital file) to be available with the border officials to be able to read the chips content

cards.q: How, then, is the information read by a border official in another country
cards.a: Because this special key is distributed to all border organisations in different countries

cards.q: Is it not possible to **hack** the system
cards.a: Yes, but it is difficult because the RFID chip system requires the reader to be within **6 inches** of the chip

cards.q: How much of memory does the chip have
What are the weaknesses of digital passports
cards.a:
1. RFID chip data **can be read** by any reader from a few cms away
2. The chip data is **not mandated** to be encrypted
3. Digital signatures **do not bind to a particular chip**; hence passport cloning is technically possible
4. Possibility of **biometric data leakage** possible

cards.q: What happens if one loses their e-passport
cards.a: No different than when one loses their traditional passport. One needs to inform the passport office and follow the procedures to get a new one issued.

cards.q: Which was the first country to issue e-passport
cards.a: **Malaysia** in **1998**

_data.title: Carbon Footprint
_data.description: Know more of how all of us can save the planet
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is a Carbon Footprint
cards.a: Carbon footprint is the total greenhouse gas emissions caused by an individual, event, organization, service, place or product

cards.q: What are Greenhouse Gas Emissions
cards.a: These are emissions from human activity that strengthen the Greenhouse Effects (*separate deck available*)

cards.q: What are Greenhouse Effect
cards.a: The greenhouse effect is a process when energy from sun goes through its atmosphere and warms Earth's surface, however the atmosphere prevents the heat from returning directly to space, resulting in a warmer planet

cards.q: How are these emissions expressed
cards.a: As carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e)

cards.q: What would be somes example of estimated CO2e
cards.a:
1. A load of laundry washed at room temperature will be **0.6 kg** of CO2e
2. A new car has a foot print of approximately **9 tonnes** of CO2e
3. A flight has an emission equivalent of more than **200 gms** of CO2e per km and a rail coach almost a quarter of it

cards.q: What determines the CO2e of a product
cards.a:
The true carbon footprint of any product includes emissions resulting from: 
- the manufacturing process
- the transportation of the product to warehouses etc
- indirect emissions, such as those caused by the manufacturing of the materials used

cards.q: As individuals why should we care about our carbon footprint
cards.a: Because of our lifestyles and choices made, we add to the greenhouse gas emissions that causes global warming

cards.q: What are some of the choices individuals can make to reduce our carbon footprint
cards.a:
Yes. Small changes can be made. Some of these are:
1. Consume local (*less transportation*) and seasonal products (*less storage*)
2. Avoid excessive plastic packaging
3. Use public transport (*distributed footprint*) instead of private vehicles
4. Unplug electronic equipment when charged

cards.q: What is a **Carbon Calculator**
cards.a: These are websites that provide a convenient form-based enquiry of one's lifestyles to give an estimate of the total footprint for a period

cards.q: What is **Carbon accounting**
cards.a: It refers to processes used to measure how much carbon dioxide equivalents an organization or individual emits

cards.q: What is **Carbon credits**
cards.a: A carbon credit is a tradable certificate or permit representing the right to emit one tonne of carbon dioxide or the equivalent amount of a different greenhouse gas

cards.q: What is **Carbon Offset**
cards.a: A carbon offset is a reduction or removal of emissions of carbon dioxide or other greenhouse gases made in order to compensate for emissions made elsewhere

cards.q: Besides Carbon footprints are there other ecological footprints
cards.a:
Yes.
1. **Water footprints**: that determine the extent of water use in relation to consumption by people
2. **Land footprints**: that determine the real amount of land required to produce a product

_data.title: E Ink Color Display
_data.description: Know more about this technology
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **e-ink**
cards.a: It is a type of **Electronic paper** made by E Ink Corporation

cards.q: Is it popularly used
cards.a: The most popular use has been in ebook readers

cards.q: How is it different from the display units of a mobile, computer or TV
cards.a: These digital display units use **backlight technology** to display text and images

cards.q: What is **backlight** display
cards.a: A backlight is a form of **illumination** used in *liquid crystal displays* (LCDs) since LCDs do not produce their own light. Usually they illuminate from the back of the LCD display panel.

cards.q: Is not most of the ebook readers black and white display
cards.a: Yes. Black and White e-ink displays are the ones used in all ebook readers

cards.q: Is Color e-ink a new technology
cards.a: Yes, and is not commercially popular yet. Scientists are working on creating vibrant colors that brings all the advantages of e-ink technology to the user.

cards.q: When was the first color e-ink technology introduced
In what way are e-ink displays better than LCDs
cards.a:
1. It is closer to natural reading
2. It consumes very less battery power

cards.q: Why is reading on an e-ink better than conventional digital displays
cards.a: Because it mimics the appearance of **ink on paper** which reduces eye strain

cards.q: How does reading on e ink paper reduce eye strain
cards.a: This is because it doesn't reduce **our blink rate** unlike LCD displays

cards.q: Why does e-ink displays consume less power
cards.a: This is because these displays require power only to **change content** on the display but not to display the content unlike backlit displays that require the illumination at all times

cards.q: What is the technology behind e-ink display
cards.a:
1. These displays have tiny **microcapsules** that are suspended in a liquid that is encased within a film layer.
2. When these microcapsules receive a positive charge, they are white in color and they become black when a negative charge is applied.
3. Once applied it remains in that state till the values are changed

cards.q: What happens when content is changed
cards.a: All the microcapsules in the display unit are changed to either positive or negative state based on the content and layout of the page. To do this, it requires power. However, when the user is reading the page, there is no power required since there are no changes to the page.

cards.q: Does this mean that it consumes battery power only when we **turn** a page
cards.a: Yes. Because all the microcapsules need to get reset based on the new page's content.

cards.q: How long does the battery last on an e-book readers
cards.a: This is of course based on usage. But usually it lasts in weeks unlike mobiles which run out of power within a day!

cards.q: Why is color e-ink not popular
cards.a: The technology has been more difficult to *crack*. Several versions have been released, but they seem unsatisfactory in terms of quality of display vis-a-vis power required

cards.q: What is the limitation of e-ink technology
cards.a:
1. Today, it is largely black and white
2. It needs light to fall on it to be visible (*which is good in a way*) but that prevents reading something in darkness (unlike mobile phones)
3. Videos cannot be played using this technology

_data.title: COP 26
_data.description: About the achievements of this climate change global conference
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of COP 26
cards.a: Conference of Parties 26

cards.q: What is this conference about
cards.a: It was the United Nations sponsored conference on **Climate Change**

cards.q: What is 26
cards.a: The 26th edition of the UN Climate Change Conference

cards.q: Where and when was it held
Who was the President of the Conference
cards.a: Mr Alok Sharma, a UK cabinet minister

cards.q: What are these conferences
cards.a: The United Nations Climate Change Conferences are yearly conferences held in the framework of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)

cards.q: What is the purpose of the Climate Change Conferences
cards.a:
1. Essentially, to access the progress in dealing with climate change
2. To get countries bide by the obligations discussed in earlier COP conferences

cards.q: How many countries participated in COP 26
cards.a: 197 participating agencies

cards.q: Were there specific goals to the COP 26
cards.a:
1. Secure global net zero by mid-century and keep 1.5 degrees within reach
2. Adapt to protect communities and natural habitats
3. Mobilise finance
4. Work together to deliver

cards.q: What were the achivements listed during COP 26
cards.a:
1. Over 90% of world GDP is now covered by net zero commitments and 153 countries have put forward new 2030 emissions targets.
2. 80 countries are now covered by either Adaptation Communications or National Adaptation Plans to increase preparedness to climate risks.
3. Developed countries have made progress towards delivering the $100 billion climate finance goal and will reach it by 2023.
4. Collaboration between governments, businesses and civil society will work to deliver climate goals faster

cards.q: What is **Net Zero** related to environment
cards.a: A term, popularized - *thanks to COP26* - for saying a country, company, or product does not contribute to global greenhouse gas emissions

cards.q: What were the key takeaways from COP 26
cards.a:
1. Strengthen efforts to build resilience to climate change
2. Curb greenhouse gas emissions
3. Provide the necessary finance for both
4. transparent reporting of climate actions and support provided or received, including for loss and damage

cards.q: Why is Paris Agreement considered important
cards.a:
Back in 2015, at COP21, in Paris, something momentous happened:
- every country agreed to work together to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees and aim for 1.5 degrees
- to adapt to the impacts of a changing climate
- to make money available to deliver on these aims

cards.q: Where and when was the first COP conference held
cards.a: In Berlin, Germany between 28-Mar-1995 to 7-Apr-1995

cards.q: When and where is the next COP 27 conference scheduled
cards.a: In Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt scheduled in 2022

_data.title: Covid and its Variants
_data.description: Know more on the variants of covid
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Covid
cards.a: Short for **Covid-19**, it is the newly identified disease that causes respiratory illness

cards.q: When was Covid identified
cards.a: World Health Organisation (WHO) first learned of this new virus on 31 December 2019

cards.q: How did Covid get its name
cards.a: **Co** is for Corona, **Vi** for Virus and **D** for Disease

cards.q: What is the difference between Covid-19 and SARS-Cov-2
cards.a: Covid-19 is the infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus

cards.q: Who issued the official names of Covid-19 and SARS-Cov-2
cards.a: The official names COVID-19 and SARS-Cov-2 were issued by WHO on 11 February 2020

cards.q: What is the full form of SARS-Cov-2
cards.a: **S**evere **A**cute **R**espiratory **S**yndrome - **Co**rona**V**irus - **2**

cards.q: What is the incubation period of Covid
cards.a: 1 to 14 days

cards.q: What are the common symptoms of Covid
cards.a:
1. Fever or chills
2. Cough
3. Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
4. Fatigue
5. Muscle or body aches

cards.q: How does any virus spread
cards.a: To spread, a virus needs to infect a host, replicate and produce lots of copies of itself

cards.q: What is a virus Mutation
cards.a: When a virus replicates it doesn't always manage to produce an exact copy of itself via a process called Mutation

cards.q: In what way does a virus change
cards.a: The new copied virus may start to differ slightly in terms of its genetic sequence

cards.q: What is a Variant
cards.a: Viruses that get produced with new mutations are called variants

cards.q: What is a Strain
cards.a: When a new variant has different functional properties to the original virus and becomes established in a population, it is sometimes referred to as a new **strain** of the virus

cards.q: So is a strain and variant the same
cards.a: All strains are variants, but not all variants are strains

cards.q: How are the variants of Covid-19 named
cards.a: An expert group convened by WHO recommended using letters of the Greek Alphabet, i.e., Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta

cards.q: What is the first Covid variant named
cards.a: Alpha

cards.q: What is the list of variant names so far
cards.a:
1. Alpha 
2. Beta  
3. Gamma
4. Delta
5. Omicron

cards.q: What are some of the variants being monitored
cards.a:
1. Lambda
2. Mu

cards.q: What is the full form of PCR test
cards.a: **P**olymerase **C**hain **R**eaction **T**est

cards.q: What is the full form of RT-PCR test
cards.a: **R**everse **T**ranscription **P**olymerase **C**hain **R**eaction  Test

cards.q: What does PCR testing do
cards.a: PCR tests are used to directly screen for the presence of viral RNA (Ribonucleic Acid) in the body

cards.q: What is the full form of CT value in a RT-PCR Test
cards.a: **C**ycle **T**hreshold value

cards.q: What is the CT value that determines whether a patient has covid or not
cards.a: Popularly a value below 35 is considered positive and above being negative (*this threshold can vary from country to country*)

cards.q: What are covid antibody / antigen tests
cards.a: They are tests done to detect corona proteins in a person's body to know if they has immunity against covid-19

cards.q: Can an antigen test detect presence of covid
cards.a: No, they cannot diagnose covid

_data.title: Diamonds from Air
_data.description: Know more on how this possible
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: Is this for real
cards.a: Yes. Scientists have been able to create diamonds using the **Carbon Dioxide** from the air.

cards.q: How is Carbon Dioxide converted into Diamonds
cards.a:
1. Carbon Dioxide from the air is captured
2. Carbon is extracted from it
3. It is purified and crystallised into Diamond
 
> Diamond is just **crystalline carbon**.

cards.q: Is that why they are called **carbon-negative diamonds**
cards.a: Yes. The technology behind this production **reduces the carbon footprint** in the atmosphere. Hence the name.

cards.q: Is this the same as **synthetic diamond**
cards.a: No. Synthetic Diamond is diamond that is produced in a **controlled technological environment** that *replaces the geological processes* that natural diamond requires to create it.

cards.q: What are **Lab-based** diamonds
cards.a: Same as **Synthetic Diamonds**

cards.q: In what way are Diamonds from Air different from Lab-based diamonds
cards.a: Lab-based diamonds still use **fossil fuels** products unlike carbon-negative diamonds which uses the *carbon from the air*!

cards.q: What are **Imitation Diamonds**
cards.a: These are materials or stones with **gemological characteristics** similar to those of a diamond

cards.q: What are the problems of traditional diamond mining
cards.a:
- Deforestation
- Water pollution
- Worker exploitation

cards.q: What are the benefits of carbon-negative diamonds
cards.a:
1. **Environment friendly**
2. Natural stones **supply is dwindling** so this becomes a *new source* to meet the growing demand of diamonds

cards.q: Is it cheaper to produce diamonds from air
cards.a: Current Not. Folks behind this project are hoping that with **subsidies** and **popularity**, the price will reduce

cards.q: Has anyone started production of such diamonds
cards.a: A company named **Aether** are offering jewellery made with such diamonds

_data.title: Digital Denim
_data.description: Know more about the digital alternative
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: How is digital denim different from regular denim
cards.a: It uses Ink-jet printing technology on cloth to give a denim effect

cards.q: Why would someone want to do do this for something that seems perfect!
cards.a: That is because making denim is **not environment friendly** and consumes massive amounts of water

cards.q: How is denim made conventionally
cards.a:
1. Cotton is gathered
2. Then, put into machines and spun together into strong threads
3. The threads are dipped several times into tubs of indigo dye
4. The indigo threads are woven together
5. The denim is then *sanforized*, i.e. stretched, heated, and shrunk down

cards.q: So it is step 2 that consumes lots of water
cards.a: Yes, the repeated wash is required to give the faded look that is so typical of a denim

cards.q: How is digital denim made
cards.a: In this method, the ink jet printer drops textile colourants onto the surface of the fabric

cards.q: Is this similar to how digital prints are made on Tees
cards.a: Yes. Except that the *type of ink jet printer* and the quality of the *colourants* are different and suitable to give a denim look

cards.q: What are the advantages of digital denim
cards.a:
1. It uses less water
2. It uses less energy
3. It is a print-on-demand process
4. It is easy to create a denim of any color

cards.q: What about the thickness of the denim
cards.a: For this process, one would choose pre-treated fabric that has the same weight and texture as the traditional jean samples

cards.q: In what way is digital printing in clothing industry an advantage over conventional methods
cards.a: To print using the traditional process, as you increase the number of colors, you increase the cost of the cloth. In Inkjet printing costs are not a function of the number of colors but just the area of printing.

cards.q: How is the faded look achieved in digital denims
cards.a: High resolution images of denim samples are taken and then these get transferred to the fabric

cards.q: How close is the digital denim to the original denim
cards.a:
One of the teams, led by *Lisa Chapman* and *Ming Wang* of the North Carolina University, showed samples to industry experts and the following were their findings:
1. **On color**: on a scale of 1-5 (five being closest), the digital denims scored a 3.
2. **On texture**: good match
3. **On lightness**: good match
4. **On line quality**: not a good match

cards.q: What was the single most unmatching feature between the two denims
cards.a: The **penetration** of the color. On digital denims the colors is *kind of* on the surface while with traditional dye printing it gets absorbed in the underlying fabric.

cards.q: Are digital denims available commercially
cards.a: Not yet as per reports. Labs are researching to remove some of the drawbacks to make it a commercial success given the environment benefits it will bring.

_data.title: DALL·E 2
_data.description: Understand the versatility of this AI engine
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **DALL·E**
cards.a: It is an **artificial intelligence program** that can create original, realistic images and art from a text description

cards.q: What sort of images can this AI program create
cards.a:
For example a text like: **An Astronaut riding a horse in photorealistic style** will generate:

sourced from openai website

cards.q: What type of textual information can be provided for image creation
cards.a: It can combine **concepts**, **attributes**, and **styles**

cards.q: What would be another example
cards.a:
1. **Concept**: A bowl of Soup 2. **Attribute**: that looks like a monster 3. **Style**: made out of plastine will generate:

sourced from openai website

cards.q: Besides creating images can DALL-E make changes to existing images
Can it change the style of an existing image
How does it work
cards.a: DALL·E 2 has learned the relationship between images and the text used to describe them. It uses a process called **diffusion**, which starts with a pattern of random dots and gradually alters that pattern towards an image when it recognizes specific aspects of that image.

cards.q: What is the full form of DALL-E
cards.a: It is a *portmanteau* of **WALL-E** and **Salvador Dalí** (*the famous painter*)

cards.q: Is WALL-E the same as the movie
Who created this AI program
cards.a: The OpenAI, an AI Research and deployment Company

cards.q: What is DALL·E 2
Can this technology be misused to generate violent or adult images
cards.a: No. The team behind WALL-E ensures that **violent**, **hate**, **adult** and other **explicit content** cannot be generated using this program.

cards.q: How do they control this misuse
cards.a: DALL·E is an AI program that has been **fed** with thousands of images called **training data**. By controlling this data, they ensure that the program does not *understand* these harmful concepts.

cards.q: What about faces of Celebrities
cards.a: In a similar manner, they have ensured that faces of public figures are not part of the training data

cards.q: Is DALL·E 2 available for use
cards.a: Not yet. Researchers and others can apply for limited access to this tool.

_data.title: Digital Twin
_data.description: Is this about having a replica about ourselves? Know more
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What do we mean by Digital Twin"
cards.a: It is a **virtual model** designed to accurately reflect a physical object, process or service

cards.q: Is it like a *simulation* of sorts
cards.a: Yes. A **digital twin** is a computer program that uses real world data to create simulations that can predict how a product or process will perform

cards.q: How does it work
cards.a: Internet of Things (IoTs) gather data from the physical world via sensors and send it to the digital twin program to reconstruct

cards.q: What are the uses of building a digital twin
cards.a:
1. The feedback from the simulations are used to improve the product or service being tested
2. By integrating with IoT and Artificial Intelligence it spurs innovation
3. It identifies faults in systems and prevents their failures

cards.q: What are examples of Digital Twins
cards.a:
1. In **Healthcare** a digital twin of a patient or organs allows surgeons to practice procedures in a simulated environment rather than on a real patient
2. In **Formula 1 cars** the team can study the behaviour of the car in adverse road conditions
3. In **Smart cities**, town planners uses digital twin technology to understand and improve the life for its citizens (e.g. *Singapore**).

cards.q: When is a digital twin used
cards.a:
1. Before a product is created
2. After it is created to run tests and simulations
3. To test capabilities and run prognostics

cards.q: Which industries popularly use digital twins
cards.a:
- automotive
- healthcare
- disaster management
- retail
- power

cards.q: Who introduced the concept of digital twins
cards.a:
1. The concept of digital twins was first put forward by David Gelernter’s 1991 book *Mirror Worlds,*. 
2. However,  **Michael Grieves** is credited with applying the concept to manufacturing in 2002.
3. But it was John Vickers of NASA who introduced the term in 2010.

cards.q: When was the concept of digital twins first used
cards.a: NASA first used the idea to improve the physical model simulation of spacecraft in 2010

cards.q: What are the important components of a digital twin
cards.a:
**Data** and **Modeling**
 
- Data about the product, its lifecycle, design, material parts etc
- Analytical models that use the data to understand its effect on fatigue, failure and stress

cards.q: What are the benefits of digital twins
cards.a:
1. Save costs by reducing maintenance
2. Reduce accidents
3. Reduce downtime

cards.q: Do human digital twins exist
cards.a: Yes. It aims to create Digital Twins that reproduce not only the *outer aspects* of a human being, such as physical and physiological characteristics, but also **inner qualities** such as *personality*, *sensibilities*, *thoughts* and *skills*.

cards.q: What could be the uses of a human digital twin
cards.a:
1. Use a digital twin as an interface
2. Create a personal agent to work on ones behalf
3. By merging capabilities of twins, one could potentially build a twin that has the best of each individual twin

_data.title: Earth Day
_data.description: Know more about its purpose and history
_data.author: rmr

links.title: Home to the Earth Day movement

cards.q: When is **Earth Day** celebrated
cards.a: It is held every year on **22-April**

cards.q: What is its mission
cards.a: The Earth Day's mission is to **diversify**, **educate** and **activate** the *environmental movement* worldwide

cards.q: What happens during Earth Day each year
cards.a:
Millions of people across the planet participate in activities like:
- planting of trees
- picking up litter
- limit water usage
- turn off lights
- ride a bike to work instead of fuel-based transportation
- participate in educating youth on saving the planet

cards.q: When did Earth Day begin
cards.a: It was first held on **22-Apr-1970**

cards.q: How did this movement begin
cards.a: Senator **Gaylord Nelson** of US was concerned about the deteriorating environment in US and thought of building awareness in colleges. He asked his colleague, **Pete McCloskey** to join him in this crusade.

cards.q: Did some specific incident trigger the idea of such a movement
cards.a: Yes. It was the **massive oil spill** in Jan 1969 on the shores of Santa Barbara, California, US that triggered this initiative

cards.q: Who led the movement in 1970
cards.a: **Denis Hayes**, a young environment activist, was chosen to bring students from the campus to participate in the events in 1970

cards.q: Does the date 22-April have any specific relevance
cards.a: The organisers wanted a weekday falling between Spring Break and Final Exams, to maximize the greatest student participation

cards.q: Was it a global event to begin with
cards.a: No. It became a global event in 1990 when leaders from many countries approached Denis Hayes to organise a campaign across the planet. That year about **200 million** across **144 countries** participated.

cards.q: How popular is the event today
cards.a: In recent years, Earth Day has become a global event with over a **billion people** across most countries in the planet participating in the day's events and ensure that the mission is alive

_data.title: Finland's Education System
_data.description: Know more of its features that make this unique educational system so effective
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **appreciable** about the Finland's Education System
cards.a:
1. People believe that it embodies the country's embedded values of **being honest**, **fair**, **down-to-earth**, and **trusting others**
2. That it contributes to why Finland is the **happiest** country in the world
3. That the students have a high **reading proficiency** as well as **high life satisfaction**

cards.q: How is the educational system structured
cards.a:
1. **Pre-school**: ages 6-7
2. **Comprehensive School**: ages 7-16
3. **Upper Secondary School/ Vocational School**: ages 16-19
4. **Bachelor Degree**: an additional 3-4 years
5. **Masters Degree**: an additional 2-3 years
6. **Doctorate**

cards.q: What are some of the elements that contribute to its success
cards.a:
1. Equal Opportunities
2. Learning through Play
3. Personalised Learning
4. Lack of standardized testing
5. Minimal homework
6. Technology driven
7. Lifelong learning
8. Inclusive education
9. Autonomous teachers

cards.q: Is education free for all in Finland
cards.a: The school system is 100% funded and college education is highly susidised

cards.q: What are the highlights of their early education system
cards.a:
1. High-class daycare and kindergarten system to develop cooperation and communication skills
2. No formal school till the age of 7!
3. An emphasis on respect for each child's individuality and chance for each child to develop as a unique person

cards.q: Is reading considered an important part of education
cards.a:
Yes. This is evident from:
1. **Maternity package**: Parents of newborn babies are given three books: one for each parent, and a baby book for the child
2. **Reading for pleasure** is encouraged
3. **Free books** are provided to children
 
> Finland publishes more children's books than any other country

cards.q: What are some **unique** features of their educational system
cards.a:
1. They spend **low number of hours** in school: starts 8-9 am and ends at 2 pm
2. For every 45 minutes of learning, students **enjoy 15 minutes of play**
3. Students are **not measured** at all for the first six years of their education
4. They have **minimal homework** permitting them to pursue after-school play and hobbies
5. Schools are **not ranked** in any way
6. Finnish teachers have the same *status* as doctors and lawyers
7. **No private schools**: All schools are public funded

cards.q: What is the teachers selection process
How are teachers held accountable for their role
How is admission to graduate programs done
cards.a:
It is :
1. based on high-school final GPA
2. fully transparent, merit based and objective
3. with no essays
4. with no human factor in selection
5. with no weight on extracurricular activities

cards.q: What is the ideology behind the Finnish educational system
cards.a: That education should be an **instrument to balance out social inequality**

_data.title: World's first Pig Heart Human Transplant
_data.description: Know more on why a pig was chosen and other relevant info
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: Who was the recepient of first pig-heart transplant
cards.a: David Benett at the age of 57

cards.q: When and where was the transplant done
cards.a: On 7-Jan-2022, in Baltimore, Maryland, US

cards.q: Who performed the operation
cards.a: A team of surgeons from the University of Maryland School of Medicine led by Dr Bartley Griffith and Dr. Mohiuddin

cards.q: Why was the pig chosen as the animal whose heart could be transplanted
cards.a: Because they are very similar in structure, size and function to human hearts

cards.q: Was there any treatment done to the pig before using the heart
cards.a: The pig heart had **10 genetic modifications**, including the removal of four pig genes and the addition of six human genes to ensure the host body did not reject the pig heart

cards.q: How long did the procedure take
cards.a: 7 hours

cards.q: Were any previous experiments done before the doctors undertook this procedure
cards.a:
1. In 2021, surgeons at New York University Langone Health transplanted kidneys from the same line of genetically modified pigs into two legally dead people with no discernible brain function. 
2. The organs were not rejected, and functioned normally while the deceased recepients were sustained on ventilators.
 
> As it is often said, science always **stands on the shoulders of giants**

cards.q: Was there no alternative treatment for the patient
cards.a: The patient, who had arrhythmia, was not a viable candidate for the heart transplant list or an artificial heart pump

cards.q: What is Arrhythmia
cards.a: An arrhythmia occurs when a person’s heart beats irregularly

cards.q: What is **Xenotransplantation**
cards.a: It is the process of transplanting live organs, tissues, or cells from a nonhuman animal into a human

cards.q: When was the first human heart transplant done
cards.a: Dr Christiaan Barnard with his team, performed the world's first human-to-human heart transplant operation on 3-Dec-1967

cards.q: How long did David Benett live after the transplant
cards.a: Two months. He died on 8-March-2022

_data.title: Flexible Speaker
_data.description: Check how this paper thin speaker works
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: How flexible is this speaker that has been developed
cards.a: It is as thin **as paper** and can be *bonded on almost any material*

cards.q: Who developed this technology
cards.a: Engineers from **MIT Labs**

cards.q: How do loudspeakers, in general, work
cards.a:
1. A loudspeaker uses electric current inputs that pass through a coil of wire
2. This generates a magnetic field
3. Which moves a speaker membrane
4. That moves the air above it
5. That makes the sound we hear

cards.q: How differently does the new flexible speaker work
cards.a: The new developed speaker uses a **thin film** of a *shaped piezoelectric material* that moves when voltage is applied over it, which moves the air above it and generates sound

cards.q: How much of energy is required in comparison to traditional loudspeakers
cards.a: Just a fraction. It requires about **100 millwatts** per sq meter of speaker area in comparison to about **1 watt** which is consumed by traditional speakers for the same decibel level.

cards.q: Does the surface on which the speaker is bonded to matter
cards.a: No. Tests so far have shown that it can produce high quality sound no matter where it is bonded

cards.q: What are some of the use-cases of this technology
cards.a:
1. **Immersive experiences** like 3D audio in theme parks
2. **Smart devices** applications

cards.q: What was the hurdle that the researchers needed to overcome
cards.a: Traditionally speakers are designed to be free-standing because the film must bend freely to make sound. To overcome this, they designed **tiny domes** on a thin layer piezoelectric material that could **vibrate independently**. In such a way that when the speaker material is bonded to a surface it *does not interfere* with the vibration.

cards.q: Does this mean that each dome produces a sound
cards.a: Yes, each is a **sound producing unit**

cards.q: How small are these domes
cards.a: About **15 microns** (*1/6th the thickness of human hair*)!

cards.q: Can these domes be of different sizes
cards.a: Yes, the larger domes produce more sound of lower frequency

cards.q: And the whole speaker has many such domes
Is it commercially available
cards.a: Not yet. The research team published their paper on 26-Apr-2022

_data.title: Flying Car
_data.description: Check if it is science fiction
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: How does one define a **Flying Car**
cards.a: It is a type of vehicle which can function as both a **car** and an **aircraft**

cards.q: Do **Flying cars** exist
cards.a: Yes, in the labs, not commercial yet. There has been tremendous progress to make this a reality.

cards.q: Why are Flying cars looking like a reality **now**
cards.a:
Because of the convergence of a number of things
1. **Improved Battery** technology
2. World is focussing on **sustainability** (which flying cars technology offers)
3. **On-demand services** have increased
4. **Funding** available for such projects

cards.q: How many passengers will a flying car have
cards.a: Current test models suggest about 1 to 7 passengers

cards.q: So is it like a small plane
cards.a: Yes, except the interiors will feel more like a car with seats, seat-belts and windows to enjoy the scenery

cards.q: What are the challenges in building a flying car
cards.a:
A flying car must:
1. have a safe and reliable operation both on public roads and in the air
2. need to be environmentally friendly
3. be able to fly with minimal (*like a car*) qualifications at the controls
4. come at a affordable purchase and running costs

cards.q: Will flying cars use conventional runways for flying
cards.a: The current models use both, the conventional runways as well as the Vertical Take-off and Landing (**VTOL**) like a helicopter

cards.q: When was the first flying car demonstrated
cards.a: One of the earliest was the **Aerocar** built in US in 1949. It never progressed beyond some demonstrations. It is considered as the first practical flying car

cards.q: When was the first manned flying car tested
cards.a: In **August 2020**, a Tokyo-based flying car startup *SkyDrive* successfully flew a prototype eVTOL vehicle with a pilot on board at a **test site** in Japan

cards.q: Has there been any flying car flights between cities
cards.a: Yes. The first was done between airports in **Slovakia** on **28-June-2021**: from the airports at *Nitra* to *Bratislava*

cards.q: How long was the flight duration
At what height did the flying car cruise at
cards.a: At 2500 m (8200 ft) at a speed of approximately 170 kmph

cards.q: Will Flying cars replace cars, buses or trains
cards.a: Unlikely say futurologists. In all probability, the first transport vehicle they will replace will be the **helicopter**

_data.title: Earth Hour
_data.description: Know more about its origins and purpose
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: When is **Earth Hour** celebrated
cards.a: It is held every year on the **last Saturday of March**

cards.q: What is the objective of this event
cards.a: **Earth Hour** aims to increase awareness and spark global conversations on **protecting nature**, tackling the **climate crisis**, and working together to shape a **brighter future** for us all

cards.q: When and how did it begin
How did the idea come about
cards.a: Earth Hour came from a think tank initiated by Earth Hour Co-Founder, **Andy Ridley**, that resulted in a partnership between *WWF-Australia*, *Leo Burnett* and *Fairfax Media* to address the climate change issue

cards.q: Why is it called Earth Hour
cards.a: Because for **one hour** between **8:30 to 9:30 pm** individuals, communities, and businesses are encouraged to turn off non-essential electric lights

cards.q: Why is it held in late March of every year
cards.a: This is the time of the *Spring and Autumn equinoxes* in the northern and southern hemispheres respectively, which allows for near coincidental sunset times in both hemispheres, thereby ensuring the **greatest visual impact** for a global *lights out* event

cards.q: What are the ways in which people are asked to celebrate the event
cards.a:
1. Switch off the lights
2. Attend an earth hour event
3. Organise an earth hour event

cards.q: Why switch off lights
cards.a: It is a voluntary action by its participants to **show their commitment to an act of change** that benefits the planet and is a simple gesture that all can do

cards.q: What are the types of events organised on earth hour
cards.a:
Events related to nature and then environment, such as:
1. Nature trails
2. Campaign a rally with placards to draw peoples attention
3. Turn the lights off major places of attraction
4. River clean ups

cards.q: What is another urgent threat faced by earth that is taken up as an Earth Hour mission
cards.a: The rapid **loss of biodiversity** and nature

cards.q: Does earth hour organisation have a logo
cards.a: This is the logo

cards.q: What does the 60 in the logo mean
cards.a: It represents the **60 minutes** of Earth Hour where we focus on the impact we are having on our planet and take positive action to address the environmental issues we face

cards.q: Does the plus in the logo too mean something
When did Earth Hour become popular
What is the Earth Hour forest
cards.a: In 2013, *WWF-Uganda* secured 2700 hectares of land to establish the first-ever **Earth Hour Forest**

cards.q: What were some notable achievements of this movement
cards.a:
1. In 2014, the *Galápagos Islands*, a UNESCO World Heritage site, became the first province in Ecuador to **ban plastic bags**
2. In 2016, under the Earth hour initiative 50,000 citizens of Spain urged their government to **shift from fossil fuels to renewables**
3. In 2018, in *French Polynesia*, Earth Hour inspired public pressure led to 5 million kms being classified as **Managed Marine Area**

cards.q: What is the theme of Earth Hour for 2022
cards.a: **Shape Our Future**

_data.title: Formula One Car Racing
_data.description: Check out the trivia associated with one of the most popular viewing sports
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Formula One
cards.a: **Formula One** (also known as *Formula 1* or *F1*) is the highest class of international racing for open-wheel single-seater racing cars

cards.q: Why is it called Formula
cards.a: The word **formula** refers to the set of rules to which all participants' cars must conform to

cards.q: Is there a Formula 2 and Formula 3 too
cards.a:
Yes. There are 4 levels of Formula racing for cars:
- Formula 1
- Formula 2
- Formula 3
- Formula 4

cards.q: Which is the governing body of the F1 races
cards.a: **FIA** or **Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile's**

cards.q: What is Grand Prix in F1 racing
cards.a: Each race in a season is called a **Grand Prix** or GP

cards.q: What is a season in F1
cards.a: One season consists of a *series of races* usually in one calendar year

cards.q: How many F1 races are conducted in a season
What is the schedule of F1 races in 2022
cards.a:
The first seven races will be held at:
1. **Bahrain**: 18-20 March
2. **Saudi Arabia**: 25-27 March
3. **Australia**: 8-10 April
4. **Italy**: 22-24 April
5. **United States**: 6-8 May
6. **Spain**: 20-22 May
7. **Monaco**: 27-29 May

cards.q: The next 8 races will be held at:
cards.a:
8. **Azerbaijan**: 10-12 June
9. **Canada**: 17-19 June
10. **Great Britain**: 1-3 July
11. **Austria**: 8-10 July
12. **France**: 22-24 July
13. **Hungary**: 29-31 July
14. **Belgium**: 26-18 Aug
15. **Netherlands**: 2-4 September

cards.q: The balance races will be held at:
cards.a:
16. **Italy**: 9-11 September
17. **Singapore**: 30 September - 2 October
18. **Japan**: 7-9 October
19. **United States**: 21-23 October
20. **Mexico**: 28-30 October
21. **Brazil**: 11-13 November
22. **Abu Dhabi**: 18-20 November

cards.q: How are the Champions of a season decided
cards.a: A **points system** is used at GPs to determine two annual World Championships: one for **drivers**, the other for **constructors**

cards.q: Who are **Constructors**
cards.a: Constructors are people or corporate entities which design key parts (**chassis and engine**) of Formula One cars

cards.q: What is pole position
cards.a: The **pole position** is the position at the front at the start of a racing event

cards.q: How is pole position decided
cards.a: The fastest car in **Qualifying** which is usually the day before the race

cards.q: What is podium finish
cards.a: Like in any race, the top three winners are referred to as **podium finishes**

cards.q: How are points earned by a driver in a F1 season
cards.a:
1. The winner receives **25 points**
2. The second place finisher: **18** points
3. Third place: **15**
4. Fourth place: **12**
5. Fifth place: **10**
6. Sixth to Tenth place get: **8, 6, 4, 2** and **1** points respectively
 
> **One additional point** is awarded to the driver and team with the fastest lap of the race, if they finish in the top 10 positions

cards.q: How are Constructors' points earned in a F1 season
cards.a: If both cars of a team finish in the top 10, the Constructor's points are the **sum of the driver points**

cards.q: At what speeds do F1 cars move on the track
cards.a: They move at speeds reaching upto a top speed of **360 kms/hr** (or 223 miles/hr)

cards.q: How does a race driver qualify for participation in a F1 race
cards.a:
There are 4 criteria
1. Complete **two years** in junior single seater racing events
2. Turn **18 years old to hold a license
3. Accumulate **40 race points** over 3 years in junior racing events
4. Accumulate driving **300 kms** (184 miles) in a Formula 1 car

cards.q: Can a woman compete in Formula 1
cards.a: In theory **yes**, though *no woman has made it* to any race

cards.q: What is the Flag System in F1 races
How many flags are defined and what do they mean
cards.a:
10 flags:
1. **Yellow**: Hazard on track
2. **Green**: Normal racing conditions
3. **Red**: Session is suspended
4. **Blue** A faster car is approaching
5. **Yellow & Red Stripes**: Track is slippery
 
> The other 5 flags are listed in next card

cards.q: The balance flags are:
cards.a:
6. **Black With An Orange Circle**: A driver has a mechanical issue and must return to the pits
7. **Black & White**: Warning for unsportsmanlike behavior
8. **Black** Disqualification
9. **White**: Slower moving vehicles ahead, or miscellaneous vehicles on the track
10. **Chequered** The session is finished

cards.q: When was the first F1 season held
cards.a: The first season was held in **1950** with **7 races**

cards.q: Where was the first ever GP race held
cards.a: The **French Grand Prix** was held at the Gueux circuit in Reims in 1950

cards.q: How did the tradition of spraying of Champagne begin in F1 races
cards.a: *As the story goes*, on winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1966, Jo Siffert accidentally sprayed the crowd as the bottle of champagne had been sitting out in the sun, causing pressure to build up inside the magnum. The next year, Californian racer Dan Gurney deliberately copied Siffert's gesture when he won the same race and the tradition was born.

_data.title: Gait Recognition
_data.description: Learn of his non-intrusion method of recognising people
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What do we mean by **gait recognition**
cards.a: It is the use of **behavioral biometrics** to identify a person over a *long distance without direct contact*

cards.q: What parts of a person does it use to recognise
cards.a: A gait recognition system uses the **shape of the human body** and the **way it moves** in order to identify it

cards.q: Is this similar to how facial recognition works
cards.a: Yes, just like a facial recognition system uses the **face** of a person

cards.q: How is data collected about a person's shape and movement
cards.a: **Video data** and **wearable sensors** are used to capture gait data. Another method is to use **radar** to identify moving objects remotely

cards.q: How is the data collated to be later used to recognise the person
cards.a:
**Machine learning** algorithms analyse the data. Broadly, the steps are
1. **Capture gait data** via videos
2. **Silhouette segmentation** is done by extraction from these videos
3. **Contour detection** is the next step
4. Finally, **feature extraction** is used to classify the person

cards.q: Does this mean that gait recognition can be done only if the persons data has been captured
How is gait recognition used in real life
cards.a: Usually with **surveillance cameras** in crowdy places for security purposes

cards.q: What are the advantages of gait recognition
cards.a:
1. It is less **touchy-feely** than other biometric verification systems such as *retinal scans* or *fingerprints*
2. It is **non-invasive** and can be applied without *user consent*

cards.q: Why would it be better than facial recognition
cards.a:
1. At times, it is difficult to capture the face of a person in a crowd from a distance
2. It is easier for someone to change one's face
3. It is a little difficult to camouflage one's gait

cards.q: What is the error rate of gait recognition technology
cards.a: Lab tests have show an error rate of only **0.7%**

cards.q: What are the disadvantages of gait recognition
cards.a:
1. It requires **specialised equipment** like sensors and hi-res cameras to capture one's gait
2. A person can be recognised only if their data has been recorded in advance and **stored in the database**

_data.title: Gene Editing
_data.description: Know more about how CRISPR is changing the world of gene editing
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is a Gene
cards.a: A gene is the basic physical and functional unit of heredity

cards.q: What do we mean by Gene Editing
What is the full form of DNA
cards.a: **d**eoxyribo**n**ucleic **a**cid

cards.q: Why would someone need to change the DNA
cards.a: Editing the DNA can lead to changes in physical traits, like eye color, and reduce disease risk

cards.q: How does this technology work
cards.a: Scientists can cut the DNA at a specific spot (*like a scissor*) to remove, add, or replace the DNA

cards.q: What is CRISPR
cards.a: A new DNA editing tool that was invented in 2009 that makes gene editing simple, better, faster and cheaper than before

cards.q: Is it the same as Gene Therapy
cards.a: Often the two words are used to mean the same. In gene editing, a mutated gene is revised, removed, or replaced at the DNA level. In gene therapy, the effect of a mutation is offset by inserting a *healthy* version of the gene.

cards.q: What types of diseases can be corrected by Gene Editing
cards.a: **Genetic diseases**, which are conditions caused by one or more mutations in the genome

cards.q: What are some of these diseases
cards.a:
Gene Theraphy targets rare diseases for which effective treatment options are not available:
1. Hemophilia
2. Cystic Fibrosis
3. Muscular Dystrophy
4. Sickle Cell Anemia
5. beta-thalassemia

cards.q: At what age is Gene theraphy administered
Is Gene editing done before the birth of a child
cards.a: Yes. **Prenatal Gene Theraphy** is easily done and more effective. Often done by injecting the treatment into an *umbilical* blood vessel

cards.q: When was the first successful Gene editing done
cards.a: In 1990, 4-year-old Ashanthi de Silva became the first gene therapy success story

cards.q: What are the disadvantages of Gene editing
cards.a:
1. Unintended side effects
2. Increased likelihood of developing cancer
3. May be used in biological attacks
4. Unintended consequences for future generations

_data.title: Green Burial
_data.description: The eco-friendly burial
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: How is burial normally carried out
cards.a: Cemeteries often require that the body be placed in a **metal or wooden casket** and then placed inside a **concrete or metal vault**

cards.q: What do we mean by a **Green Burial**
cards.a: It is a form of burial where the body is not **prepared with chemicals**, or **buried in a concrete vault**

cards.q: What is the thinking behind green burials
cards.a: To eliminate all the **negative effects** burials have on the environment

cards.q: In what way can a green burial reduce this negative effect
cards.a:
By:
1. **limiting waste**
2. **reducing carbon footprint**
3. **nourishing local ecosystem**

cards.q: How can a burial be made green
cards.a:
- by **eliminating embalming**
- using a **shroud** 
- or a **biodegradable** casket

cards.q: Is not embalming necessary
cards.a: No. It is done to **preserve human remains** for public display through the use of a chemical mixture that **delays decomposition** and makes the body *look natural*

cards.q: Would not the contaminants of a body affect the environment
cards.a: Proper soil and water setbacks need to be in place to ensure that the contaminants from the body do not enter the surrounding water

cards.q: Is there not a belief that the microorganisms found in the soil near a cemetry are harmful
cards.a: When location of a cemetry is properly planned, there is little evidence to suggest this. Further, the microorganisms involved in the decaying process (*putrefaction*) are **not pathogenic**.

cards.q: How long does it take for a body to decompose in green burials
cards.a: About 4-6 weeks

cards.q: Why do people choose green funerals
cards.a:
1. Simplicity
2. Low cost
3. Conserving natural resources
4. Eliminating hazardous chemicals
5. Preserving natural areas

_data.title: Greenhouse Gases
_data.description: Know more of its effects on the environment
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Greenhouse effect** and **Greenhouse gases**
cards.a: The **Greenhouse effect** is the process by which energy from the sun warms our planet but the atmosphere prevents the heat from returning back due to **Greenhouse gases** resulting in a warmer planet

cards.q: Is it not good to retain the heat from the Sun
cards.a: Yes, if not Earth will always be below freezing temperature. This natural Greenhouse effect is why we survive

cards.q: Then, why is it considered harmful
cards.a: Because the amount of heat retained is more than required gradually making the planet warmer which will eventually destroy it

cards.q: Which are the Greehouse gases
cards.a:
The primary greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere are:
- Water Vapor
- Carbon Dioxide
- Methane
- Nitrous Oxide 
- Ozone 
- Chloroflurocarbons

cards.q: Which are the major Greenhouse gases that prevent heat from radiating back
cards.a:
1. Carbon Dioxide
2. Nitrous Oxide
3. Methane
4. Chloroflurocarbons

cards.q: Why is there always mention about Carbon Dioxide
cards.a: Because that constitutes a major percentage (about 76%) of the GHG

cards.q: What happens when the heat is not radiated back
cards.a: Certain quantity of the heat is required to maintain equitable temperature on earth, but over time because of the increase in these gases the planet has become warmer

cards.q: What happens if the planet becomes warmer
cards.a: It contributes to extreme weather, wildfires, droughts and food supply disruptions that may eventually lead to extinction of animal species

cards.q: Which industries are the major emitters of GHG
cards.a:
1. Power generation via coal
2. Transportation
3. Agriculture
4. Deforestation

cards.q: Why happens when we use coal
cards.a: Coal when it is burnt to generate energy releases tremendous amount of Carbon Dioxide. This causes a disproportionate amount of CO2 in the atmosphere causing global warming. This happens with other fossil fuels like petroleum products too.

cards.q: How does Agriculture contribute to GHG
cards.a:
1. Cattle herds produce Methane when they gas. Methane is 30 times more potent than CO2.
2. Crop fertilisers contain Nitrous Oxide which is 300 times more potent than CO2.

cards.q: How does Deforestation increase GHG
cards.a: Trees, we know, absorb Carbon Dioxide, during the photosynthesis process. This reduces the amount of CO2. However, with large deforestation, the world is denied of this beneficial process.

cards.q: How can humans reduce GHG
cards.a:
1. Switch to cleaner energy providers
2. Drive less and walk / cycle more
3. Wash clothes without using warm water in washing machine to save energy
4. Eat seasonal or locally produced fruits/vegs since they have lower transportation costs
5. Replace light bulbs with energy-efficient ones

_data.title: Gudi Padwa
_data.description: Know more about this festival
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Gudi Padwa**
cards.a: It is a *spring time festival* celebrated by Hindus in many parts of India

cards.q: What does *Gudi Padwa* mean
cards.a: **Gudi** is the *flag* of Lord Brahma and **Padva** is the *first day* of the lunar month

cards.q: Is it a new year in the Hindu calendar
cards.a:
Yes. **Maharashtrian**-speaking, **Konkani**-speaking, **Telugu**-speaking and **Kannada**-speaking folks celebrate this day as their New Year
 
> Telugus celebrate it as **Ugaadi**
> Kannadigas celebrate it as **Yugadi**

cards.q: How is the festival celebrated
cards.a:
1. Houses are cleaned and freshly plastered
2. Women and children work on intricate rangoli designs
3. Folks buy new clothes
4. Families meet and celebrate the occasion

cards.q: What is the significance of the Gudi
cards.a: **Gudi** is a stick decorated with a bright cloth, neem leaves, and garlands is unfurled outside every house. It is believed that this will ward off **evil spirits** and bring **prosperity** in the house.

cards.q: What food delicacies are usually prepared
cards.a:
1. *Puran polis* and *Shrikand* by Maharashtrians
2. *Pacchadis* recipe of sweet and bitterness by Telugus
3. *Rava laddu*
4. *Basundi*

cards.q: Does the festival mark any historical event
cards.a: It is believed that this festival is celebrated to commemorate the coronation of Rama post his return to Ayodhya after completing 14 years of exile

cards.q: Being a spring-time festival is it celebrated in other parts of India
cards.a:
Yes, the onset of spring is celebrated on different dates but around the same time
1. as **Baisakhi** by Punjabis
2. as **Vishu** by Malayalis
3. as **Puthandu** by Tamilians
4. as **Pohela Boishak** by Bengalis
5. as **Bihu** by Assamese
6. as **Cheti Chand** by Sindhis
7. as **Navreh** by Kashimiris

_data.title: Holi: The festival of Colors
_data.description: Know some interesting history of this festival
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Holi**
cards.a: A Hindu festival that celebrates the arrival of Spring

cards.q: When is Holi celebrated
cards.a: It is observed on the **last full moon day** (*Purnima*) of the month of **Falgun**, 12th Hindu calendar month

cards.q: Why is it called the **festival of love**
cards.a: Because as on this day people get to unite together *forgetting all resentments* and all types of bad feeling towards each other

cards.q: How is Holi celebrated
cards.a: People gather with friends and family, both kids and adults, to celebrate this festival of colours. Everyone is seen playing with colours, splashing water balloons on one another, dancing to tunes and enjoying some scrumptious snacks.

cards.q: How long is the festival celebrated
cards.a: It starts in the evening of the full moon day and celebrated till the next evening

cards.q: Why is Holi celebrated
How is the ritual started
What is the effigy that is burned the previous evening
cards.a: "The effigy is of Holika, the devil minded sister of King Hiranyakashyap. which is placed in the wood and burnt

cards.q: What is the literal meaning of Holi
cards.a: Holi means **burning**

cards.q: What was the original name of Holi
cards.a: Holika

cards.q: Why are colors thrown on one another during Holi
cards.a: It is believed that Lord Krishna was sad over his dark complexion and wondered why his companion *Radha* was so fair. So his mother *Yashoda* suggested that he smear her face with colors to change her complexion to what he wanted

cards.q: What gadgets do people use to spray or smear colors on one another
Is there any scientific reason associated with Holi colors
cards.a: It is believed that in ancient times, when people started playing Holi, the colours used by them were made from plants like **Neem, Haldi, Bilva, Palash**. The playful pouring and throwing of color powders made from these natural sources has a **healing effect** on the human body.

cards.q: Is there a *puja* (worship) done on Holi day
cards.a: No. It is meant to be a day of joy and celebration.

cards.q: Is the festival celebrated throughout India
What is *Bhaang* that is popularly served during Holi
cards.a:
It is a flavoured intoxicating recipe consisting of:
- cannabis leaves
- almonds
- spices like cinnamon, clove and cardamon
- ginger, rose water
- sugar
- milk

cards.q: What is *Thandai* recipes that is also served during Holi
cards.a:
**Thandai** means something that cools one's body. The recipe consists of:
