cards.a: If the person *recognises* it to be a panic attack (because they have had it in the past) then the best suggestion is to wait it out since they know that it **will pass**

cards.q: How important is breathing in controlling an attack
cards.a: Very important and most effective. Normal breathing is *12-20 breaths* per minute. During an attack this **doubles**. So reducing it to **5 per minute** with *exhales longer than inhales* greatly helps.

cards.q: What is the science behind why slow breathing helps
cards.a: This type of breathing stimulates the **vagus nerve** (the longest nerve in the body) which carries the signals and sensory information from and to the brain and regulates functions like heart rate and digestion

cards.q: Is panic attack same as anxiety attack
cards.a: No. Panic attacks are sudden while anxiety attacks usually occur due to prolonged worry about something.

cards.q: Why have panic attacks increased in the world
cards.a: Doctors do not seem to have an exact answer. But many attribute this presumed increase in anxiety disorders to factors such as **social media**, **poor sleep habits**, **work-related stress** and **loneliness**.

_data.title: What are Character Strengths
_data.description: Get a quick peek into they are
_data.author: nanc

cards.q: What are Character Strengths
cards.a: Simply put, these are the good qualities that people possess: *a collection of positive traits that show people's strengths*

cards.q: How has the term of Character Strengths (CS) come about
cards.a: It has been derived from the field of **Positive Psychology**

cards.q: What is Positive Psychology
cards.a: **Positive psychology** is the scientific study of what makes life most *worth living*, focusing on both individual and societal well-being

cards.q: How is CS related to Positive Psychology
cards.a: Research suggests that Character Strengths impact happiness including development of resilience & positive relationships

cards.q: How do we describe Character Strengths
cards.a: Character Strengths is about how you relate to other people and the world around you

cards.q: Why are these CS important
cards.a: Research shows that focusing on and using Character Strengths helps all - *children as well as adults* - to improve health, happiness and our sense of self worth

cards.q: Are they different from skills / talents
cards.a: Yes. Talent, Skills or Knowledge need the **support** of character strengths to be *honed, nurtured and developed*

cards.q: Are we inborn with Character Strengths
cards.a: Yes. But they have to be **discovered**, **valued** and **used**

cards.q: What are Inner Strengths
cards.a: These are strengths that we are born with

cards.q: How many such inner strengths do we have
cards.a:
They have been categorised under:

1. Wisdom & Knowledge
2. Courage
3. Humanity
4. Justice
5. Temperance
6. Transcendence

cards.q: What are strengths under **Wisdom and Knowledge**
cards.a:
1. Creativity
2. Curiosity 
3. Judgement & Open mindedness
4. Love of Learning 
5. Perspective

cards.q: What are strengths under **Courage**
cards.a:
6. Bravery
7. Perseverance or Grit
8. Honesty
9. Zest

cards.q: What are strengths under **Humanity**
cards.a:
10. Capacity to Love & be Loved
11. Kindness
12. Social Intelligence

cards.q: What are strengths under **Justice**
cards.a:
13. Fairness
14. Teamwork
15. Leadership

cards.q: What are strengths under **Temperance**
cards.a:
16. Forgiveness & Mercy 
17. Modesty & Humility
18. Prudence 
19. Self regulation

cards.q: What are strengths under **Transcendence**
cards.a:
20. Appreciation of Beauty & Excellence 
21. Gratitude 
22. Hope 
23. Humour 
24. Religiousness & Spirituality

cards.q: Are these all the strengths we have
cards.a: There are many more but the above 24 help people lead flourishing lives

cards.q: Do CS differ across people around the globe
cards.a:
No. All the Character Strengths remain same across:
- Gender
- Class
- Race
- Culture
- Geography

cards.q: Can these CS be developed or enhanced
cards.a: Yes. All strengths can be built and developed by everyone. All our Character Strengths can grow. Though some of these strengths have the tendency to be stronger in some and not in others. That is why we have our **unique personalities**.

cards.q: Why should we develop our CS
cards.a: Because it is a very powerful tool,  *which we all already have*, for tapping into our best self and being able to lead a more flourishing life

cards.q: What do we need to do to realise its full potential
cards.a: We need to connect with the Character Strengths daily and use them with full awareness to realize its positive influence in our life

_data.title: What are Cryptocoins
_data.description: A non-technical understanding
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is a Cryptocoin
cards.a: A **Cryptocoin** is a crypto asset that has its own blockchain

cards.q: What do we mean by *a crypto asset*
cards.a:
- Crypto means **hidden** or **secret**, and
- Asset is something of potential value
 
> A crypto asset is a digital asset of value that is encrypted using secret keys

cards.q: What do we mean by *having its own blockchain*
Is Bitcoin a cryptocoin
What are other popular cryptocoins
cards.a:
1. Ether
2. Tether
3. Binance
4. Solana
 
> The most popular amongst the above is **Ether**, a cryptocoin that runs on the **Ethereum** blockchain

cards.q: Other than for a currency need, why would one have a cryptocoin
Why would people trade in cryptocoins
cards.a:
1. Just like they trade in any other asset viz. expect that the value of the asset grows over time 
2. serves as a *currency** to purchase products and services

cards.q: What are crypto tokens
cards.a: They are like cryptocoins but do not have their own blockchain. They piggyback on some other blockchain.

cards.q: What is an example of a crypto token
cards.a: Basic Attention Token (**BAT**) is a token built on Ethereum that is used to avail of marketing and advertisement services

cards.q: There seems little difference between a crypto coin and crypto token
cards.a: Yes. Both are crypto assets. A coin is a token but a token is not a coin!

cards.q: What are **altcoins**
Is there a term called *shitcoins*
Is there another term called *memecoins*
cards.a: Yes. **Memecoins* are meme-inspired crytocoins and are influenced by social media and like *shitcoins* have no identifiable purpose

_data.title: What are Life Skills
_data.description: A brief understanding
_data.author: nanc

cards.q: What do we mean by **Life Skills**
cards.a: Life Skills are skills that are necessary for leading our day-to-day life to the best of our capabilities

cards.q: Is there a text-book definition for Life Skills
Is there a simpler definition!
cards.a:
Simply put, this means:
1. Anyone can learn Life Skills (LS)  
2. All of us can improve behavior by practice
3. One needs to use LS to lead a fulfilling life

cards.q: In which areas of our lives do we require Life Skills
cards.a:
In all:
- Personal
- Professional
- Social

cards.q: Why is it important to develop Life Skills
cards.a: We live in a social environment requiring us to interact with people. LS helps doing that task effectively.

cards.q: How does Life Skills help us
cards.a: It helps us balance our lives well by coping with Life’s challenges effectively

cards.q: Which are the other skills
cards.a:
Some of these include:
- Literary Skills
- Language Skills
- Employability Skills
- Sports skills
- Cultural Skills
- Survival skills

cards.q: How are Life Skills different from other skills
cards.a: Life Skills are **Psycho-Social** in nature while most other skills are **Pyscho-Motor**

cards.q: What do we mean by Pscho-Social skills
cards.a: **Psycho** means related to the *mind* and **Social** means related to *living together*, interacting with others

cards.q: What do we mean by Pscho-Motor skills
cards.a: Skills which are **technical** in nature like *language*, *vocational*, and *employability*

cards.q: Are there different types of Life Skills
cards.a:
As per WHO the core life skills fall under 3 categories:
1. Thinking Skills 
2. Social & Emotional Skills
3. Coping Skills

cards.q: What are **Thinking Skills**
cards.a:
1. Critical Thinking
2. Creative Thinking
3. Problem Solving
4. Decision Making

cards.q: What are **Social and Emotional** skills
cards.a:
1. Self Awareness
2. Empathy
3. Interpersonal relationships
4. Effective Communication

cards.q: What are **Coping Skills**
cards.a:
1. Coping with Emotions
2. Coping with Stress

cards.q: In summary, what are the 10 Life Skills
cards.a: (1) Critical Thinking (2) Creative Thinking (3) Problem Solving (4) Decision Making (5) Self Awareness, (6) Empathy (7) Interpersonal relationships (8) Effective Communication (9) Coping with Emotions and (10) Coping with Stress

cards.q: What is **Critical Thinking** skills
cards.a: It is the ability to analyze information & experiences in an objective manner

cards.q: What is **Creative Thinking** skills
cards.a: It is the ability to generate new ideas by combining, changing or reapplying existing ideas

cards.q: What is **Problem Solving** skills
cards.a: It is the ability to deal with any problem in a constructive manner

cards.q: What is **Decision Making** skills
What is **Self Awareness**
cards.a:
It is the knowing of our**self**:
- our character 
- our strengths
- our weaknesses
- our desires
- our likes and dislikes
- our skills

cards.q: What is **Empathy**
cards.a:
It is the ability:
- to be sensitive to another person’s situation
- to understand her/his concerns, worries, fears, and needs 
- to understand how they feel

cards.q: What is **Interpersonal Relationship**
cards.a: It is the ability to: *establish*, *sustain*, *grow* or even *end* relationships with a **positive note**

cards.q: What is **Effective Communication**
cards.a: It is  the ability to **listen**, and **express** *verbally* through spoken or written language, and *non-verbally* through gestures and body movements in ways that are *culturally acceptable*

cards.q: What does **Coping with Emotions** mean
cards.a: It is the ability of being aware of many different types of emotions , how these emotions influence human behaviour and being able to respond, deal or manage the emotions appropriately

cards.q: What does **Coping with Stress** mean
cards.a:
It is the ability which helps:
- in recognizing the **sources of stress** in our lives
- understanding how this **affects** us physically, emotionally & mentally
- learning how to **cope, deal or manage** with it effectively

cards.q: What are some challenges faced during student life
cards.a:
- Exploring identity and self image
- Managing self esteem, self expectations, academic pressure & competition
- Coping with peer pressure and social media influence

cards.q: What are some challenges faced during adulthood
cards.a:
- Handling Employability, Self Esteem, Work pressure & Competition 
- Sustaining relationships and Parenthood 
- Managing Work-Life balance

cards.q: What are some challenges in the Elderly phase
cards.a:
- Health issues
- Economic insecurity
- Boredom & Loneliness 
- Neglect
- Low Self Esteem

_data.title: What are Smart Contracts
_data.description: Know more of this new way to execute business processes
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What are **Smart Contracts**
cards.a: Smart contracts are **digital contracts** that **automatically** execute, control or document legally relevant events and actions according to the terms of a contract or an agreement

cards.q: What are some examples of smart contracts
cards.a:
1. **Property title** can get automatically transferred on digital confirmation of the money transfer
2.  **Insurance Claims** processing can be speedened up and less fraudulent if the policies are drawn up using smart contracts
3. **Peer to Peer** loans are already been done using this technology

cards.q: Who coined the word smart contract
cards.a: A computer scientist **Nick Szabo** in 1994

cards.q: Are smart contracts linked to blockedchain
How does it work
cards.a: In a smart contract there can be **as many conditions** that need to be met for a **particular task** (say, *transfer some money*). And if the data represented in the blockchain has that information, it can immediately perform the task without a human intervention.

cards.q: What are the benefits of smart contracts
cards.a:
1. **Speed, Efficiency and Accuracy**: no paper-work, no reconciliation 
2. **Trust and Transparency**: no third party involvement
3. **Security**: they are encrypted
4. **Savings**: no lawyer fees and no delays

cards.q: Which are some of the applications that can benefit from smart contracts
cards.a:
- **Finance**: payments based on completion of tasks
- **Insurance**: reimbursements / payments when due
- **Health**: authentic information of drug batches etc
- **Voting**: quick, authentic and better voter participation

cards.q: Do smart contracts have legal binding
cards.a: No. They are not legal contracts but are a **technology means** of performing obligations deriving from other agreements.

cards.q: Are smart contracts recognised by any country
cards.a: **Belarus** became the first country to recognise smart contracts in **2017**. In many other countries including *UK* and *US*, smart contract obligations are admissible in court.

cards.q: What is **Ethereum** and how is it connected with smart contracts
cards.a: Ethereum is a **decentralised open-source blockchain** network (*like Bitcoin*). It is the most **popular blockchain* with **smart contract capability**. This enabled programmers to develop systems that could use smart contracts in them. Ethereum was developed in 2015.

_data.title: What are Xenobots
_data.description: Are they living organisms?
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What are Xenobots
cards.a: These are **synthetic lifeforms**, designed by computers, made to perform certain functions

cards.q: How is it pronounced
cards.a: *Zee-no-bots*

cards.q: Are they some form of robots
cards.a: There is debate whether they are *robots* or *organisms* because it is made of biological tissues. That is why they are referred to as **living robots**!

cards.q: What makes a robot *a living one*
When was the first Xenobot invented
cards.a: The xenobots were first designed in 2020 on a supercomputer at the University of Vermont and then assembled and tested by biologists at Tufts University in Massachusetts

cards.q: Who were the team that build it
cards.a: They were built by Douglas Blackiston according to blueprints generated by an AI program, which was developed by Sam Kriegman and Michael Levin, a Professor of Biology

cards.q: What material are xenobots made of
cards.a: Stem cells of the African Clawed Frog

cards.q: How big is a Xenobot
cards.a: about 1mm wide

cards.q: What is the process by which baby xenobots are created
Do Xenobots respond to stimuli
cards.a:
No. Yet they are described by scientists as "lifeforms" since:
- they can feed off of energy supplied by their cells
- move with intent
- repair their injuries 
- build other xenobots

cards.q: Do they have a brain and other organs like other organisms have
cards.a: No. They have no brain or digestive system or other conventional organs

cards.q: What is the primary use of Xenobots
cards.a: To understand how cells build things and how they go out of control. It could lead scientists to understand and prevent rogue cells from causing diseases like cancer

cards.q: What are the other potential uses of Xenobots
cards.a: These are early days for Xenobots. Scientists and Researchers are betting on the primary characteristic of xenobots which is to **corral a group of cells**. This will help confine them to perform different tasks like say *clean micro-plastics from the ocean*

cards.q: Can Xenobots be used in Medicine like Nanobots
cards.a: Yes. Xenobots could potentially be used to create patient specific cells that deliver drugs wherever intended, bypassing the challenges associated with other ways to deliver cells

_data.title: What is 3D Printing
_data.description: An overview
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is 3D printing in a sentence
cards.a: Creation of 3 dimensional products using a special type of printer

cards.q: How is it different from normal printing
cards.a: Printing, as we commonly understand, is applying ink or paint in two dimensions on surfaces like paper, cloth, plastic, wood. While 3D print is a type of manufacturing that creates products like toys.

cards.q: Is it the same as **Additive** printing
cards.a: Yes. Because layers of a material are added to make the product.

cards.q: What type of products are popularly made using 3D printers
cards.a:
- toys
- equipment frames like bicycle handles
- sporting goods
- car components
- music instruments

cards.q: What are the advantages of 3D printing
cards.a:
Unlike conventional manufacturing, 3D printing can be done:
- in a small place / workshop (even at home)
- with minimal investments
- in small quantities 
- for prototyping product ideas before full-scale production

cards.q: How is a 3-dimensional product *printed* using a printer
cards.a:
1. The 3D printing process turns a whole object into thousands of tiny little slices or layers
2. Then, each slice is made from the bottom using special material
3. Thes tiny layers stick together to form a solid object

cards.q: Is a 3D printer a special type of printer
cards.a: Yes. Unlike the normal printers that use ink to apply on the surface of materials like paper, a 3D printer uses certain materials in power form to form the layers of the product.

cards.q: What are some of the materials used
cards.a:
The materials used need to be in powder form with glue.
1. **Plastic** is the most popular used material
2. **Metal powders** like Aluminium, Steel etc where strength is required
3. **Carbon Fibre** used popularly as a coating over plastic
4. **Graphene** because of its strength and conductivity

cards.q: How are **instructions** given to make a 3D product
cards.a:
1. 3D printers require a computer to which it is attached
2. It uses a specialised software called **Computer Aided Design** (CAD)   
3. The product is designed with the order in which the layers have to be applied
4. Finally, the printer is loaded with the desired material (*similar to how we load an ink cartridge*)

cards.q: Is there a limit to what can printed using 3D printers
cards.a:
Yes.
1. Only certain type of materials are available that can be used
2. Since it uses an additive technology, only products that will not easily fail (*break, bend or fracture*) by this layer method can be manufactured
3. There is a limit to the dimensions of what can be printed

cards.q: Is it cheaper to make a product using 3D printing
cards.a: Depends. It is definitely cheaper when *not-so-large quantities* are to be made and when the product has some *intricate design* where the die costs may be prohibitive.

cards.q: What are some of the newer items being experimented with 3D printing
cards.a:
1. **Houses**: Pre-fabricated houses have been in vogue for a while. Now, these prefab components can be made using 3D printers.
2. **Car components**: Auto ancilliaries are being made esp with new materials being used in 3D printing
3. **Jewellery**: Intricate designs can now be made via a computer

_data.title: What is 4D Printing
_data.description: Is this the future?
_data.author: rmr

links.title: Self Printing Surface Cube from MIT Labs

cards.q: What is 4D printing
cards.a: 4D printing is the process through which a 3D printed object **transforms itself** into another structure with some stimuli

cards.q: What are the stimuli that can change an object
cards.a: The effect or influence of external energy input as **temperature**, **light** or other environmental **stimuli** could change the shape and properties of the 3D object

cards.q: What is an example of a stimuli that can cause a change
Why did they call this 4D printing
cards.a: The fourth dimension is **time**. The ability of the object to change shape over time.

cards.q: Does this not mean that the material should have the property to change with stimulus
cards.a: Yes. And that is the key challenge of this technology. To find **smart materials** for all types of uses.

cards.q: So what are such materials that can be used
cards.a: Either **Hydrogels** or **Shape Changing Polymers**

cards.q: What are Hydrogels
cards.a: **Hydrogels** are polymer networks exhibit swelling/shrinking behavior when solvent molecules enter/leave the network

cards.q: What are Shape Changing Polymers
cards.a: **Shape Changing Polymers** are smart materials that have the ability to return from a deformed state (*temporary shape*) to their original (*permanent*) shape when induced by an external stimulus (*trigger*), such as **temperature change**

cards.q: What are the advantages of 4D Printing
What are some applications of 4D Printing
cards.a:
1. **Healthcare**: Pills can activate only when body reaches a particular temperature
2. **Self healing pipes**: that can heal themselves automatically if they crack or break, due to their ability to change in response to the environment’s change
3. **Fashion**: Clothes become tighter in winter
4. **Self Assembly Furniture**: A flat board will curl up into a chair by adding water or light

cards.q: Is it possible for a common man to use 4D printing
cards.a: No. Not yet. It is still being researched.

cards.q: Which are some popular institutions working on it
cards.a:
1. MIT's Self Assembly Lab
2. Harvard's Institute of Biological Engineering
3. Australian University of Wollongong
4. Singapore University of Technology and Design

_data.title: What Fingerprints reveal
_data.description: How it reveals more than identity
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is a **fingerprint**
cards.a: They are the tiny *ridges*, *whorls* and *valley* patterns on the tip of each finger

cards.q: Are fingerprints unique
cards.a: Yes, and they are formed in the womb itself

cards.q: Do twins have the same fingerprints
cards.a: No. Even twins have different fingerprints

cards.q: Do fingerprints change over time
How are fingerprints left behind
cards.a: A fingerprint is formed when a finger makes *contact with a surface*. The finger leaves behind traces of sweat and any other substances present on the finger that a person might have touched. These substances are *deposited* in the the ridges present on the finger tip.

cards.q: How are fingerprints matched
cards.a:
Using two methods:
1. **Pattern Matching**: compares two images
2. **Minutiae-based Matching**: compares location and direction of minutiae points

cards.q: What are the different parts of a fingerprint
What sort of information does a fingerprint reveal
cards.a: A fingerprint could give a **molecular signatures** revealing aspects of a person's *lifestyle* and environment, such as their *job*, *eating habits* or *medical problems*

cards.q: What is molecular signature
cards.a: A **Molecular Signature** is what molecules are identifiable from a fingerprint that is left behind by someone

cards.q: What are the type of molecules available in a fingerprint
cards.a:
There are 2 types of molecules:
1. **Sweat** molecules: that we secrete out of our sweat glands (*eccrine glands*)
2. **Contaminate** molecules that we pick up when we touch objects

cards.q: What technology is used for **molecular** and **imaging** analysis of fingerprints
cards.a: It is called **Mass Spectrometry Imaging** (MSI) technology

cards.q: How does MSI work
cards.a: When a laser beam is fired on to the fingerprint, it separates the different types of molecules present in them when fed into the MSI. In addition, it detects which part of the fingerprint those molecules are present too.

cards.q: So what type of information does this molecular analysis reveal
cards.a:
Information such as:
- what **material the person has touched** viz. medicines, someone's blood, explosives, gun-powder etc
- The sweat glands molecules reveal what **they have consumed** viz food, medications, drugs etc

cards.q: Are these molecules removed if one washes our hands
cards.a: Perhaps the *contaminate molecules* may get washed but the *sweat molecules* continously secrete for a while after one has ingested some food

cards.q: What are the uses of Fingerprint analysis
cards.a:
1. as **Identity** detection
2. as **Forensic analysis** for law enforcement

cards.q: Is Fingerprint forensic analysis sufficient to prove a person guity of a crime
cards.a: No. It is considered a **reliable** piece of evidence but not **conclusive** *beyond a reasonable doubt*.

_data.title: What is Aphantasia
_data.description: A non-technical understanding
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the condition Aphantasia
cards.a: It is the **inability** to voluntarily **create mental images** in one's mind

cards.q: What is the origin of the term
When was this condition first noticed or reported
cards.a: As early as **1880** by Francis Galton

cards.q: How is this condition detected
cards.a: Usually by **self diagnosis** when the patient herself/himself realises the lack of this ability

cards.q: Is Aphantasia something that one is born with or can it develop during growth
cards.a: Both. Some patients have reported this disability after some surgery

cards.q: Does this condition affect a large population
cards.a: Studies have shown it to be about **0.8%**

cards.q: Is there no medical method of detecting this condition other than self-reporting
cards.a: Very recently, in **April 2022**, researchers found an objective test of determining this condition by tests performed as an eye-test

cards.q: What does this test based on
cards.a: It is based on the **pupil's response** to light which is an involuntary action. The pupil, involuntarily, **dilates** between light and dark objects.

cards.q: How does this reponse differ between those with Aphantasia and those without
cards.a: When folks are shown images and asked to reimagine images that they have seen, tests have shown the the same pupil dilation occurs when imagining. However, in patients with *aphantasia* there is **no difference**.

cards.q: Is this test conclusive
cards.a: These are early days. But for the first time, researchers / doctors, have an independent way to confirm aphantasia. It would take additional work and studies to become an accepted test for this condition.

_data.title: What is APS 26
_data.description: Know more about its purpose and scope of this guide
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What does APS stand for
cards.a: **A**ssistive **P**roducts **S**pecification

cards.q: Who has created the **Assistive Products Specifications** guide
cards.a: **WHO**: World Health Organisation

cards.q: And 26 means
cards.a: It is the specification for **26 products** that help people with disabilities and the elderly

cards.q: What does this assistive guide contain
cards.a: It is a **guidebook** with *specs for 26 prioritized assistive products* that describes the minimum quality requirements for manufacturing

cards.q: What types of products come under assistive living products
cards.a: They covers **mobility**, **hearing**, **vision**, **communication**, **cognition** and **self-care**

cards.q: What is the purpose of such a guide
cards.a: The main aim of the APS is to ensure countries get supply of **good quality and affordable assistive products** for all who need them

cards.q: What are some of the products for which specs have been arrived at
cards.a:
1. Crutches
2. Hearing Aids
3. Braille writing instruments
4. Medication organisers
5. Therapeutic footwear
6. Walking Frames
 
> A link at the end of this deck points to the detailed spec of all products

cards.q: What does each Specification contain
cards.a: Each APS in the compilation describes the **functional and performance requirements** that can be used as a model to *guide manufacturing and procurement*

cards.q: What would be the specs for say a **wheelchair**
cards.a:
It should consider the following function and design requirements:
- Is the wheelchair available in a range of options (e.g. seat width, seat depth, frame length,back-support height)?
- Does the wheelchair have adjustment options?
- Is it possible to customize the wheelchair for individual needs?
- Is it easy to store and transport ?
- Is the wheelchair appropriate to the user's environmental and functional needs?

cards.q: Will WHO help the countries in procuring these products too
cards.a: Yes. To start with WHO plans to issue a joint tender for wheel chairs and hearing aids with manufacturers to ensure adherence to specs as well as supply cost effective products

cards.q: Is this a first in the creation of such a guide
cards.a: Yes, it is the first global guide for **quality-assured assistive products** and will be updated regularly

cards.q: Are other international organisations helping in this effort
cards.a: WHO and **UNICEF** signed a *Joint Action Plan on Assistive Technology* to bring a catalytic impact and provide quality assistive products to the 900 million people that are lacking it

cards.q: What activities are being initiated by UNICEF to ensure success in providing assistive products
cards.a:
1. UNICEF is analyzing and updating its products in their **Supply Catalogue** to ensure they are disability-friendly
2. It is introducing new assistive technology to programmes worldwide
3. It is increasing advocacy efforts to gain a global consensus for assistive technology

_data.title: What is Biomimicry
_data.description: Know how nature can influence us
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Biomimicry**
cards.a: It is a practice that learns from and **mimics the strategies** found in nature to solve human design challenges

cards.q: What is an example of Biomimicry
cards.a: Eastgate Centre, an office complex in Harare, Zimbabwe has an internal climate control system that is inspired by the **structure of termite mounds** resulting in using just about 10% energy of a conventional building of the same size

cards.q: What is the idea behind Biomimicry
cards.a: That nature has already solved many of the problems we are dealing with today, and that animals, plants, and microbes are the world's greatest engineers!

cards.q: What is the goal of Biomimicry
cards.a: To create new **sustainable** products, processes and systems to live in **harmony** with earth

cards.q: In which areas have Biomimcry been successfully used
cards.a:
- Agriculture
- Architecture
- Construction
- Energy
- Fashion
- Food waste
- Materials
- Transportation

cards.q: Who coined the term
cards.a: The term was coined in the **1970s** by German-born Austrian architect and planner **Wolf Hilbertz**, and popularized by American biologist and writer **Janine Benyus** in her 1997 book Biomimicry: Innovation Inspired by Nature

cards.q: What is an example of Biomimicry in Agriculture
cards.a: To create a healthy ecosystem in **large grasslands** one should include multiple species that serve similar functions or roles. So that in case of any *natural disaster* the redundant species (plant or animal) could survive the change even if some others perish. This has been adopted by observing natural habitats.

cards.q: Was **Velcro®** inspired by Nature
cards.a: Yes. Plants like Burdock produce seeds that are covered in tiny hooks. These tiny hooks catch on the fur of passing animals, helping the plant disperse its seeds. This inspired Swiss engineer George de Mestral, the inventor of Velcro®, to create a hook that led finally to Velcro.

cards.q: What is an example in Energy
cards.a: Wind turbines uses wind to generate power. However, there is an area in the blade where no power is generated called **root leakage**. A new design was created that mimics the **kingfisher's beak**, which allows the bird to dive into water while barely making a splash. This is due to the way the bird *pushes the fluid around its beak* as it enters water.

cards.q: Have new materials been made mimicking nature
cards.a: Yes. For example, in coastal ecosystems, oysters grab onto one another forming extensive reefs using a glue-like substance. Reefs protect the coastline from erosion. By studying the molecular structure of these glues scientists have been able to create a material similar to the cement structure of oysters having similar strength and rigidity.

cards.q: How did the Lotus plant help innovate nanotechnology
cards.a: Lotus plants remain clean because the surface of their leaves are water-repellent, or **hydrophobic**. On examination of these leaves, scientists found that they have tiny nanoscale bumps that make a water droplet form a spherical shape that rolls off. This led to **Lotus-inspired paints** and **stain-repellant upholstery**.

cards.q: Are honeycomb structures an example of Biomimicry
cards.a: Yes. For centuries the honeycomb structure has inspired product design. Depending on the material used it has excellent **strength-weight** ratio. Hence it is popularly used in aerospace, construction, furniture design and in recent times popularly seen in 3D-printing.

cards.q: What are the advantages of Biomimicry
cards.a:
1. It brings **relief** because there is hope in solving some of the planets existential problems
2. It helps us **design generously** because we can create conditions conduicive to life
3. It helps build **sustainable solutions** faster because we are adapting proven solutions found in nature

cards.q: What are the elements of Biomimicry
cards.a:
1. **Emulate**: Learning from nature and adapting them to our needs
2. **Ethos**: Understanding the philosophy of life and adopting them in our design
3. **Connect with Nature**: by observing it and understand it better

cards.q: Is Biomimicry same as Bioinspired design

_data.title: What is Augmented Reality
_data.description: A non-technical understanding
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of AR
cards.a: Augmented Reality

cards.q: What happens in AR
cards.a: Simply put, when you point the camera of your mobile to an object, *say a flower*, details of the flower may appear as an overlay on the screen. This is via AR technology.

cards.q: So it enhances real-world experiences in a way
cards.a:
Yes. In short, it allows you to interact with that object the camera focuses on. These include:
1. Giving information on the screen
2. Playing a video or audio related to that object
3. Or simply offering a menu from which to choose one or many options

cards.q: How does it work
cards.a:
1. The system captures the image to where the camera is pointed
2. Shares it with a software running either on the device or an internet server
3. An AI algorithm recognises (a best estimate) the object.
4. That results in information being put out about that object

cards.q: What are the uses of AR
cards.a:
1. Classroom Education
2. Medical Training
3. Repair and Maintenance of equipment
4. Retailing when browsing articles
5. Tourism

cards.q: Is this not similar to QR codes
cards.a: Yes, in the sense that an image is used to identify the product. Except that in a QR code system, someone will have to create a code for every object and place it near the object to be scanned. In the case of AR, you simple scan the object.

cards.q: What are AR glasses
cards.a: These are spectacles that serve the same function that the camera of a mobile does. Wearing it, the user can focus on an object, and visible on the lens will be information about it.

cards.q: Where does the AR system get this information form
How is AR different from VR (Virtual Reality)
Can AR and VR co-exist
cards.a: Yes. In a VR-based virtual world, one can *point* at objects which will bring in additional information about that object.

cards.q: Has AR become popular
How does such an app work
cards.a:
1. Imagine that you have picked an item, *say a sofa*, from the digital store front.
2. Then, point the AR app to a part of the room where you would like to place it.
3. The app has the ability to measure distances and the space available.
4. Then, as you place the sofa at the desired place, it can estimate whether it fits or not.
5. Further, as a consumer, you can check the suitability of the item in the room and try out various uphosteries.

_data.title: What is Bitcoin
_data.description: How it has stormed the financial world
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Bitcoin
cards.a: It is a type of cryptocurrency

cards.q: What is a Cryptocurrency
Is Bitcoin the only cryptocurrency
cards.a: No. There are a few thousands of cryptocurrencies. Bitcoin is one of them and the first to be introduced.

cards.q: What do you mean by digital or virtual currency
cards.a: Unlike the paper or coin representation of value of money, think of a digital currency as a unique string of characters which holds some value

cards.q: Besides being digital in what way is it different from any normal currency
cards.a: Traditional currencies are endorsed (and controlled) by the Central Bank of a country. Bitcoin has no such governing body.

cards.q: Does this mean no one owns Bitcoin
cards.a: Yes. Of sorts. There is no central bank, or banks who endorse a currency exchange between two parties like we have in conventional currency operations.

cards.q: Who created Bitcoin
cards.a: A person by the name of **Satoshi Nakamoto**. No one knows who he is (or they are).  It is the name of a presumed pseudonymous person (or persons) who developed bitcoin, authored the bitcoin white paper, and created and deployed bitcoin's original reference implementation.

cards.q: Can I send Bitcoin to another person
cards.a: Yes, you can send bitcoins to others just as well receive bitcoins from others

cards.q: Similar to how I would send or receive in a digital wallet
What can I buy with Bitcoin
cards.a: Depends. Some e-commerce sites accept bitcoin as a mode of payment in which case goods or services can be purchased using it.

cards.q: Does the price of Bitcoin change over time
cards.a: Yes. It does based on market forces. Much like shares. Except that it is unregulated.

cards.q: Are there denominations in Bitcoin, like we have in normal currencies.
So how much is 1 satoshi
Is there a transaction fee charged
cards.a: When any bitcoin transaction is done (send or receive) there is a transaction fee that is charged and net of that the amount is put in the wallet of the receiver

cards.q: Where are all the transactions stored
cards.a: Bitcoin works on a Blockchain ledger system (*separate deck available*). The transactions are stored in the ledger across all servers of the Bitcoin network.

cards.q: Does this mean every transaction is on the ledger and know to one and all
cards.a: Yes. Except there is no way of linking a person to a particular bitcoin.

cards.q: How secure is it from someone else stealing money from your bitcoin wallet
cards.a: Almost impossible. Think of it like a password. If someone has your password, then they can transfer the bitcoin to others.

cards.q: How can I buy a Bitcoin
cards.a: In an exchange similar to how you buy shares. Someone sells you a bitcoin (or part of) based on current market prices

cards.q: Who maintain the servers of the Bitcoin network
cards.a: Folks who would like to **mine** bitcoins!

cards.q: What is **Mining** in bitcoin terminology
cards.a: The servers that constitute the bitcoin distributed network **work hard** to maintain the system. For that they are rewarded by bitcoins (or part of). The process is called *Mining* and they are called **miners**.

cards.q: Can Bitcoin be infinitely generated or is it regulated in some form
cards.a: As per the original paper, it was decided to limit the total number of bitcoins to **21 million**

cards.q: Why is there a limit set for number of bitcoins
cards.a: This is to emulate the concept similar to that of physical gold viz there is a finite quantity to be mined

cards.q: And so far how many have been mined so far
cards.a: Around **19 million** bitcoins

cards.q: How much more time will it take for the remainder 2 million to be mined
cards.a: By some estimates that will take place around 2040

cards.q: Then, what happens after that
cards.a: No more bitcoins will be mined, of course. However, miners (*folks running the servers*) will continue to earn with transaction fee.

cards.q: Can cryptocoins be pegged to an existing currency
cards.a: Yes, it can. There are numerous cryptocoins that are pegged say to the US dollar. But Bitcoin is not one of them.

cards.q: Do countries accept bitcoins as an official currency
cards.a: In 2021, **El Salvador** began accepting bitcoin as a currency alongwith US Dollar

_data.title: What is Blockchain Ledger
_data.description: A simple overview for everyone
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: Is the **Ledger** in Blockchain Ledger a ledger that is commonly understood
So what is a **Blocked Ledger**
cards.a: A Block Ledger is a group of transactions called a **Block**

cards.q: What, then, is a **Blockchain Ledger**
cards.a:
A Blockchain Ledger is one when the *blocks* of a ledger are **chained together**.
 
For example: 
- if T1 (transaction 1) to T5 are in, say, block B1
- and, T6 to T12 in block B2
- We chain block B2 to the end of B1

Then these become a Blockchain Ledger

cards.q: Isn't this how all most digital ledgers work
What does **Decentralised** Ledger mean
cards.a: If a ledger is not controlled by a central computer it is called a Decentralised Ledger

cards.q: What does **Distributed** Ledger mean
cards.a: If a ledger, like a Blockchain Ledger, is available on multiple servers it is a Distributed Ledger

cards.q: What is a **node** in Blockchain terminology
cards.a: Another name for servers (computers) in the Blockchain network

cards.q: Are multiple copies of the data stored on multiple servers of the Blockchain network
cards.a: Yes.

cards.q: Is it not a waste of resources
cards.a: No, since this is the only way to prevent a single ownership of data

cards.q: What is wrong with someone storing all the data
cards.a:
This gives that party leverage to control the use of that data. 
 
Examples of centralised data are:
1. Government institutions like the Central Bank or Finance Ministry etc
2. Social networks like: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram etc
3. Digital Marketplaces like Amazon etc

cards.q: So who owns the data in a Blockchain ledger system
cards.a: Collectively, all the nodes of the Blockchain distributed system manage the data

cards.q: Then, would not the node control the data similar to how a central server has control of the data
Consensus? Meaning what
cards.a: If any node makes a change to the ledger viz. adds, removes or updates an entry then other nodes will need to validate that change before the ledger gets updated

cards.q: And how is that done
cards.a: All via the underlying blockchain ledger software

cards.q: So who can add / change the Ledger
cards.a: Only the owner of the transaction. And this is managed via encryption methods to prevent fraud.

cards.q: Why is blockchain getting the sort of attention it does
cards.a: Because it removes the existence of a third-party to validate a transaction between two individuals

cards.q: What are examples of third-party intermediaries that exist in the world today
cards.a:
1. Government who confirms that currency given by one individual to another is authentic
2. The Land records department who confirms that land owned by someone is truly that claimed by the owner
3. Digital Marketplaces that confirm the sale of an item from a seller to a buyer

cards.q: How can intermediaries be avoided via a Blockchain system
cards.a:
Yes.
1. Bitcoin is an example of a currency that is not controlled by any State or Government
2. The NFT is a classic example of the sale and purchase of assets without any broker

_data.title: What is CBDC
_data.description: Is this the future of currency?
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is full form of CBDC
cards.a: Central Bank Digital Currency

cards.q: What is a CBDC
cards.a: It is a legal currency in digital format issued by the Central Bank of a country

cards.q: How is a digital currency different from normal currency
cards.a: Currencies traditionally have been in paper (polymer) and metal form. The digital currency is a third form which is digital.

cards.q: Will the value of the digital currency be different from that of the normal currency
cards.a: No. It will be the same.

cards.q: How is digital currency payment different from online payment
cards.a:
Online Payment
1. is a digital method via which a user (account) authorises payment to another user (account)
2. needs to go through a bank settlement system
3. is a convenience over traditional banking methods for money transfers

Digital Currency Payment
1. is immediately settled, like paying in cash
2. No bank settlement system

cards.q: What are the benefits of Digital Currency
cards.a:
1. Instantaneous transfer
2. No intermediary process like bank settlement

cards.q: Is it possible to transfer paper money to digital currency and vice-versa
cards.a: Yes, it should be possible. Think of it similar to transferring an amount from your account from one bank to another of your own account in another bank.

cards.q: How will the popularity of digital currency help any government
cards.a: With increased digital financial transactions, the burden of managing physical money reduces

cards.q: Would global payments be possible between digital currencies
cards.a: Yes. And it is being discussed as a possibility. This will make the transfer of money between two parties instantaneously.

cards.q: Is the CBDC similar to Bitcoin
cards.a:
No.
1. Bitcoin is a crypto currency that does not have the backing of any government or central bank of a country.
2. Bitcoin is not legal in most countries.
3. Bitcoin rates fluctuate on buy/sell economics with no intervention unlike national currencies
4. Bitcoins are not easily tradable for goods and services like digital currencies would be

cards.q: Is there any similarity of a digital currency with Bitcoin
cards.a: In that the underlying technology viz blockchain ledger *may be used* in both cases

cards.q: Has any country issued CBDCs
cards.a: No. But many have begun pilots.

cards.q: Which are the countries that are evaluating CBDCs
cards.a:
1. UK
2. China
3. Russia
4. Japan
5. US
6. India

_data.title: What is Bossaball
_data.description: Know how it is played
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Boosaball**
In what way is it different from soccer and volleyball
cards.a: It is played on an **inflatable court** featuring a **trampoline** on each side of the net

cards.q: How did the sport gets its name
cards.a: **Bossa**, in Brazilian Portuguese means *style, flair or attitude*

cards.q: What is the aim of the game
cards.a: Like with volleyball, it is to ground the ball on the opponents court

cards.q: How many players are in each team
cards.a: 4, and it is mixed-gender

cards.q: Can both hands and legs be used to play this game
cards.a:
Yes. The game can be played with two techniques:
1. **Volleyball touch**: playing the ball once with hands or forearms
2. **Soccer touch**: every other part of the body not being the hands or arms

cards.q: How are points scored
cards.a:
The points are gained when the ball touches the ground of the opponents. The points gained depend on type of touch used.
1. with **volleyball touch**: 1 point if ball is in opponents playing area and 3 points in opponents trampoline area
2. with **soccer touch**: 3 points if ball is in opponents playing area and 5 points in opponents trampoline area

cards.q: How does a team win a game / set
How many touches are permitted before sending the ball to the opponents side
How large is the bossaball court
What is the size of a bossaball ball
cards.a: Very similar to a volleyball viz. circumference of 25-26 inches

cards.q: What are the benefits of playing this game
cards.a:
1. It is a form of **exercise** on a soft playground
2. The body is in **perpetual movement** requiring control and posture adjustment
3. The inflatable court allows players **acrobatic movements** like flips and turns
> All this leads to cardiovascular, health and fitness benefits

cards.q: Where did the game originate
cards.a: In **Spain** and was conceptualised by Belgian **Filip Eyckmans** in 2005

cards.q: What was the inspiration behind bossaball
Is bossaball a beach game
cards.a: Though it is popularly played on beaches, it can be an indoor sports too

cards.q: In which countries is bossaball popularly played
cards.a: Argentina, Brazil, Germany, Netherlands, Portugal, Singapore, Spain

cards.q: Is bossaball played in Olympics

_data.title: What is Collaboration Overload
_data.description: Know more about this recently coined term
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What do we mean by **Collaboration Overload**
cards.a: Collaboration overload is when a worker spends so much time engaging with colleagues and responding to their requests that they have *little time for their own work*

cards.q: What happens due to Collaboration Overload
cards.a: It becomes a major source of **stress**, **burnout**, and **exhaustion** at work

cards.q: What are some of the modern collaborative tools being used
cards.a:
1. Conventional phone calls
2. Traditional physical meetings
3. The popular email with its *threaded conversations*
4. Video conferencing meetings aka *zoom calls*
5. Collab tools like *Slack*, *Team spaces*

cards.q: Are there studies that estimate the percentage of time spent on collaboration
cards.a: Yes, pre-covid, studies have shown that folks spend about **85%** on *phone*, *email* and *meetings*. It is believed that has gone up since then.

cards.q: What is an indication that collaborative overload is happening
cards.a:
1. Most folks reach out to their phones first thing when they wake up
2. Many folks do that at night too when they wake up for whatever reason

cards.q: What change did the pandemic bring about regards collaboration
cards.a: People started accommodating more short meetings as a sense of accomplishment of their work, leading to exhaution

cards.q: Why is having more meetings more exhaustive than with fewer ones
cards.a:
1. One is dealing with more subjects that require attention
2. One switches across things and more rapidly between meetings
3. The to-do list is longer since there are more meetings to manage

cards.q: What are the effects of collaboration overload
cards.a:
1. Loss of Engagement
2. Attrition
3. Mental health costs

cards.q: How does this overload result in Loss of **Engagement**
cards.a: It has been found that most of these collaborations are internal to the department and leave out many folks in other pockets of the organisation

cards.q: Why does this cause **Attrition**
cards.a: The pandemic has clearly shown that many folks cannot and do not want to adjust to the new style of functioning. They are *overwhelmed* and feel compelled to follow *other pursuits*.

cards.q: What are the mental health costs associated with this
cards.a: Many folks have complained of being overwhelmed and experience a sense of *drowning*. This is not just because of collaboration but with all the changes that covid, technology and remote working has brought to the enterprise.

cards.q: How much of the collaboration overload is caused by the individual himself
cards.a:
As they say, *often you are your own enemy*!
1. Interactions may be inefficient if one has not honed one's communication skills
2. Poor time management can lead to incomplete and consequently more frequent collaboration
3. Struggling to set priorities leads to unnecessary stress too

cards.q: Are not star performers a victim of collaboration overload
cards.a: Often that is true. The more skilled and more efficient an employee, the more likely they will have their workflow interrupted by demands for collaboration.

cards.q: How do these star performers cope with it
cards.a: Ultimately, it is seen that their performance suffers because to compensate for the loss of time, they *carry home work* resulting in stress and burnout. All of which affects their well-being and becomes risks for the organisation.

cards.q: What are ways to handle collaboration overload
cards.a:
1. Set Priorities
2. Limit Distractions
3. Manage Motivation

cards.q: Are not productivity apps suppose to make one efficient
cards.a: They are a double-edged sword. Despite its intent it often results in adding *stress* to the day and *noise* while working.

cards.q: Is not email an effective communication tool
cards.a: Yes, yet the constant *ping of your inbox or chat app* kills productivity and collaboration, even if those messages are important ones.

cards.q: In what way do high-performers collaborate better
cards.a: Studies have shown that they have learnt the art of **driving innovation** via their networks

cards.q: Is there some different way they collaborate
cards.a: Again studies have indicated that they spend about 20% to 25% more time exploring possibilities of working together with teams and partners because they understand the value of doing that!

cards.q: Who introduced the term **Collaboration Overload**
cards.a: The term has been used in articles of *effective network in organisations* for about a decade now. One of the known voices has been **Rob Cross** who recently authored a book: **Beyond Collaboration Overload**: *How to Work Smarter, Get Ahead, and Restore Your Well-Being*

_data.title: What is Dark Web
_data.description: Know more about its anonymity and untraceability
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the **Dark Web**
cards.a: It is the **hidden** collective of internet sites only accessible by a *specialized web browser*

cards.q: Is it part of the internet
cards.a: Yes, in the sense it rides on the same infrastructure that we call the internet

cards.q: In contrast is there a **Light Web**
In what way is the Dark Web different from the Open Web
cards.a:
- Users are anonymous
- No one can trace where any user request is made
- No internet search engine can **crawl** through its pages

cards.q: Since when has the Dark Web been in existence
cards.a: It is not known but the term first emerged around 2009

cards.q: Is Deep Web and Dark Web the same
What are parts of Deep Web that is not part of Dark Web
Who created the technology behind the Dark Web
What is **Tor** in the Dark Web
cards.a: It stands for **The Onion Routing**. It was the project that the US Naval Research Lab set up to build the anonymity that is now associated with the Dark Web.

cards.q: What is the **specialised web browser** required to access the Dark Web
cards.a: The TOR browser would be one such browser

cards.q: What is special about the TOR browser
cards.a: Conventional browsers like the Chrome, Edge, Safari and others follow a direct route between your computer and the web site. In a TOR browser, it uses uses a *random path of encrypted servers *called nodes*.

cards.q: How does this method of routing help
cards.a: This allows users to connect to the deep web without fear of their actions being tracked or their browser history being exposed

cards.q: Is TOR the only network of the Dark Web
cards.a: No. There are others like: **Freenet**, **I2P** and **Riffle**

cards.q: Why are illegal activities associated with the Dark Web
cards.a: Because it is convenient to conduct **business** without revealing one's true identity

cards.q: What is identity in *digital business*
cards.a: Identity in digital transactions means having knowledge of some address like: email or phone number or even **IP address** (location)

cards.q: What are some of the activities that are conducted in the Dark Web
cards.a:
1. Arms deals
2. Selling Drugs
3. Ransomware
4. Child Pornography

cards.q: Would not payments of these activities expose the people involved
cards.a: No. Because they would resort to the new forms of digital currencies like Bitcoin.

cards.q: Is it illegal to access the Dark Web

_data.title: What is Deepfake
_data.description: Technology has its dark side too
_data.author: rmr

links.title: A deepfake video of David Beckham

cards.q: What do we mean by **Deep Fakes**
cards.a: It is an artificially produced photograph or video or audio to that seems real with the idea to deceive viewers / listeners

cards.q: How did the name Deep Fakes come about
What is **Deep Learning**
What are examples of Deep Learning
cards.a:
1. Creating and sharing videos of famous people when in actual they have not recorded it.
2. Superimposing someones photos on another photo without easily detecting it
3. Creating photos of a person who does not exist!
4. Creating audio in a voice of a famous person giving an impression that it is an original recording

cards.q: How is a Deepfake video made
cards.a:
1. Usually, one targets a video to use as a basis of the deepfake.
2. Next, one requires many videos of the person one wants to insert in the video.
3. The collection of videos are fed to a Deep Learning program that builds a computer model.
4. The last step is when the targeted video is fed to the model which will replace the original person's face with the target's face, matching the mouth and eye movements

cards.q: What is an Autoencoder in a deepfake program
cards.a: The **Autoencoder** is a deep learning AI program tasked with studying the video clips to understand what the person looks like from a variety of angles, and then mapping that person onto the individual in the target video by finding common features

cards.q: What is the use of GANs in a deepfake program
cards.a: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), detects and improves any flaws in the deepfake within multiple rounds, making it more real-like

cards.q: Can deepfakes be detected
cards.a: Yes. Programs are available that can detect if a video or audio is a deepfake or not. Like any other battle, the deepfake programs try to stay one step ahead of the fake detectors

cards.q: When did deepfakes start
cards.a: The technologies leading to it began more than a decade back, but with advances in Machine Learning, somewhere in 2017 many pornographic videos of celebrities began showing up that indicated its effectiveness

cards.q: Are deepfakes illegal
cards.a: More and more countries are passing laws that treat deepfakes as being fraudulent and illegal to post in social media and elsewhere unless it is explicitly mentioned.

cards.q: What is Synthetic Media
What are some of the good use-cases to use synthetic media
cards.a:
1. Educator can now deliver innovative lessons that are far more engaging than traditional visuals 
2. It can bring historical figures back to life for a more engaging and interactive classroom
3. Famous paintings like the *Mona Lisa* can be made accessible to more folks
4. Audio story telling can be generated at a fraction of the production costs

cards.q: Is there an example of famous personality using deepfake
cards.a: Yes. A health charity partnered with David Beckham to produce a video and voice campaign to help end malaria. In the *malaria no more* campaign, Beckham spoke nine languages seamlessly for public appeal (see video link at end of the deck).

_data.title: What is Doxxing
_data.description: Know more about this violation of privacy
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the **Doxxing**
Why is this called doxxing
cards.a: It originates from the word **Dox** meaning *documents* popularly used in the courier industry. In essence, doxing is *revealing of documents* about a person

cards.q: What are the types of data that are viewed as personal
cards.a:
- full name
- home address
- work place
- other identifiable details

cards.q: Does our profile in social media be construed as doxxing
cards.a: No. Because this is something that folks fill themeselves.

cards.q: What about apps that require us to share our name and address like e-commerce and e-retailing apps
So how does doxxing take place
cards.a:
There are folks who make it their business to extract personal information and sell them by:
- **searching** publicly available *databases*
- **analysing** social *media posts and profiles*
- **hacking** websites
- conducting **social engineering**
- creating **fake sites** to lure folks to share personal information

cards.q: What sort of problems are caused by doxxing
cards.a:
- **receiving threats** on anonymous posts because now the author's details may have got revealed
- **silencing conversations** by revealing the name of the person with that view
- **blackmailing** folks who have visited *sensitive* sites

cards.q: Is Doxxing illegal
Have governments been accused of doxxing
cards.a: Unfortunately yes. Claims have been made that those in power use it as a tool to **silence the opposition**.

cards.q: Can we prevent from being doxxed
cards.a: Unfortunately not. But steps can be taken to protect oneself from getting doxxed.

cards.q: What do individuals do to protect themselves from getting doxxed
cards.a:
1. Folks try to find a **balance** between expressing themselves and protecting their identity
2. Some just prefer to be **anonymous**. But it does not always work.
3. Some use **pseduonymous accounts** in their social media and in that sense do not reveal their true identity

_data.title: What is Edge Computing
_data.description: Know more about it
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What do we mean by **edge computing**
cards.a: It is a form of computing that is done **near a particular data source**, minimizing the need for data to be send and processed in a remote data center like a *cloud*

cards.q: What is an an example of edge computing
cards.a: **Autonomous cars** today constantly capture data from cameras and other sensors. This data needs to be processed within the car itself to make split second decisions. This is an example of edge computing.

cards.q: If not edge computing what is the alternative
cards.a: The data could be sent to remote servers on some internet cloud that would process it and give back the result. However, in some use-cases that would be fatal or useless because it is too late.

cards.q: What devices can have edge computing
cards.a: Almost any device. **Mobiles phones** have enough power to achieve some amount of edge computing and for the rest send it to cloud servers. Most **IoTs** (Internet of Things) devices have some edge computing capabilities.

cards.q: What are the advantages of edge computing
cards.a:
1. **Low latency**: since the data is being processed locally, the system does not rely on networks for getting results
2. **Higher security**: since the data is not transferred to a remote location like a cloud server
3. **Reduced costs**: since no data or partial data is sent to remote servers

cards.q: Are there some types of computing that cannot be done on the edge
cards.a:
1. It could be possible that the **computing power** required to process the data is not possible at the device.
2. At times, the data collected from the source has to be **analysed** in conjunction with all **historic data**. Again something that would not be able at source.

cards.q: What are examples of edge computing tasks that are done at closer to the source of data
cards.a:
1. **IoT cameras** are used to *measure foot falls*
2. **Display** of *air pollution data* on Digital Boards
3. **Drones** flying over vast lands to identify *pest infestations*

cards.q: Why has edge computing gained importance in recent times
cards.a: The tremendous **increase in computing power** and storage that is available in a small chip is making edge computing an **important strategy** in deployment of technology.

cards.q: Which industries are popularly deploying edge computing
cards.a:
1. Agriculture
2. Autonomous vehicles
3. Enegry
4. Health
5. Retail
6. Transportation

_data.title: What is e-skins

cards.q: Is e-skin some sort of an **electronic skin**
cards.a: Yes. They are **flexible**, **stretchable** and **self-healing** electronics that are able to mimic functionalities of human or animal skin

cards.q: How do e-skins work
cards.a:
E-skins have sensors embedded to measure:
- pressure
- temperature
- humidity
- airflow
- electrolyte balance
- bio-markers

cards.q: Where is e-skin used

1. In Robotics
2. In Prosthetics
3. In Health Monitoring Technologies

cards.q: How do e-skins help in Robotics
How do e-skins help in Prosthetics
cards.a: People using prosthetic arms and other organs could now get a better sense of feel and touch which are so important and fundamental to *feeling normal*

cards.q: How do e-skins help in health monitoring devices
cards.a:
1. Wearable electronic devices with skin-like properties can provide continuous and real-time monitoring of human signals
2. Drug delivery devices can also be integrated into electronic skin to enhance its performance

cards.q: What material is e-skin made of
cards.a: Either **polymer-based** or **hybrid materials**

cards.q: How thin is an e-skin
cards.a: Researchers in Tokya have been able to make them as thin as **2 micrometres**

cards.q: What material is an e-skin made of
cards.a:
Different types of (network of) **polymers** that are cured at a specific temperature have been used as e-skins
2.

cards.q: How is e-skin placed on the body
cards.a: This is similar to how temporary tattoes are applied viz. place it on skin and rub it with water

cards.q: What is the self healing property of e-skin
cards.a: Similar to how human skin can autonomously heal from wounds to restore its mechanical and electrical properties, electronic skins contain **chains of molecules** that can easily rearrange themselves when they sense changes such as tears!

cards.q: Since when are e-skins been in use

_data.title: Gorpcore: the new fashion trend
_data.description: Impress others with your knowledge on this latest fashion trend
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Gorpcore
cards.a: It is a fashion style that fuses **streetwear** and **sportswear** with **camping** and **hiking outfit** components

cards.q: What does the word Gorpcore mean
cards.a: The term **gorp** is an acronym for *good ol' raisins and peanuts*, a phrase that refers to the trail mix snack enjoyed by hikers and nature enthusiasts

cards.q: Who coined the term **Gorpcore Fashion**
cards.a: **Jason Chen** of *The Cut*

cards.q: What are the elements of a Gorpcore clothing
cards.a:
It is a combination of:
- Colors
- Layering
- Volume
- Fit
- Logo

cards.q: How are the colors in Gorpcore distinguishable
cards.a:
1. Colors are **bright** as is preferred for outdoor activities for safety purposes
2. Colors are usually: *Orange, Red, Yellow, Pink and Purple*
3. Combos with: *Beige, Brown, Olive Greens* are popular

cards.q: What layering is preferred in Gorpcore
cards.a:
1. **Multiple layers** of clothing is fundamental to Gorpcore fashion
2. The combinations of such layers are critical to the style

cards.q: Is Gorpcore minimalistic
cards.a: It is anything but minimalistic. Being a layered style, the clothes are **bulky**. The coats are **oversized** because they are worn above (layered) others. The trousers are **wide and straight**, with *large, convenient pockets*.

Yes. These include

5. **Base layer**: often full sleeved
6. **Hiking Boots / Sneakers**
7. **Gloves**

cards.q: When did this trend start
When did it gain popularity
