cards.q: Is it a hot trend in 2022
cards.a: Many of the global shopping platforms like *Lyst* place it amongst the top trends of the year

_data.title: What is GPT-3
_data.description: A non-technical understanding
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of **GPT**
What is a **neural network**
cards.a: Neural Network is a type of **algorithm** used in *machine learning* to recognise patterns in data to solve problems

cards.q: And is GPT-3, version 3
What type of problems does GPT solve
cards.a: GPT is *trained* to generate **realistic human text**

cards.q: What do we mean by **trained to**
cards.a: All machine learning problem solving involves creating a **model** (algorithm) based on data that is **fed** into the system. In the case of GPT, massive amounts of *internet data* was used.

cards.q: What are the type of text outputs that GPT can generate
cards.a:
1. Creation of text
2. Conversations
3. Text Summarization
4. Question-Answering
5. Programming code!

cards.q: What are its **Text Creation** capabilities
cards.a:
Given a small initiation text of a few words or sentences, the GPT system can generate large quantities of:
- articles on the topic
- blogs
- stories
- news reports
- poetry

cards.q: Poetry? Can it generate in the style of an old poet
cards.a: Yes. It is particularly good at that! ... *Shakespeare*, *Edgar Allen Poe* etc

cards.q: Does the **text summarizations** capabilities include **text simplification**
cards.a: Yes. For example, giving a command like: **summarize this for a second-grade student** followed by the text will create an appropriate summary with vocabulary suitable for a second-grader

cards.q: Can GPT answer questions asked in normal language
cards.a: Yes. These can be general questions that are available in the **public domain**, or can be questions from a **passage** that you have provided.

cards.q: Does the Q&A capabilities include multiple choice questions too
cards.a: Yes. It has the *intelligence* to guess alternatives for the multiple choice!

cards.q: Will GPT-3 replace programmers
Who has created GPT-3
cards.a: **The OpenAI**, an AI Research and deployment Company

cards.q: What sort of complexity and size is the GPT-3 model built on
Does this mean that GPT-3 models have **knowledge** or **intelligence** as we commonly know
cards.a: No. The model itself has no knowledge, it is just good at **predicting the next word(s)** in the sequence.

cards.q: Does GPT-3 support all languages
cards.a: Since a majority of the training data was in English, it performs much better in English over other languages. However, it does support a number of other languages

cards.q: Is the output of a GPT generated text always correct and without bias
cards.a: No. Remember that GPT has no **absolute knowledge** of anything. It's output is based on the training data on which the model has been created. Hence if that data is biased or abusive, so would be the output of some task given to it.

cards.q: What are the uses of GPT-3
cards.a:
1. Support teams can use them for customer questions (chat bots)
2. Marketing teams can use them for copy and collateral generation
3. Teachers can use them to create exam question papers
4. Students can use them for topic summaries

cards.q: What was the training data for GPT-1 and GPT-2
cards.a:
1. GPT-1 released in 2018 had 117 million parameters
2. GPT-2 released in 2019 had 1.5 billion parameters
3. GPT-3 release in 2020 had 175 billion parameters
 
> number of parameters is a measure of the complexity of the model and results in better generation of output

cards.q: Will there be a GPT-4
cards.a: In all likelihood. Every generation of GPT makes it more powerful

_data.title: What is Green Steel
_data.description: Know more of this carbon saving steel
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **green steel**
cards.a: Steel that is produced with a much **lower amount of carbon emissions**

cards.q: How is traditional steel manufactured
cards.a: A type of *carbon* called **Coke** reacts with the oxygen at very high temperatures in **iron ore** to purify the metal to a form that is used to make steel

cards.q: Does this process result in high carbon emissions
cards.a: Yes. In fact, steel making is estimated to contribute to about 7-9% of world carbon emissions

cards.q: How is the process of **green steel** different
cards.a: It uses one that reduces the use of carbon. Various methods are being tried out. The one that has been more successful is replacing carbon by **hydrogen**.

cards.q: How does Hydrogen help purify iron ore
cards.a: The hydrogen, *freed from water*, reacts with the oxygen in ore at high temperatures, with fossil-free wind energy and hydropower. This releases **hydrogen and water**, instead of *carbon dioxide*. The resulting **sponge iron** melts in an electric arc furnace with a **small amount** of carbon to create steel.

cards.q: How much of carbon emission does this process release
cards.a: Less than **2%** of the coke-based methods

cards.q: Is green steel commercially used today
cards.a: No. It is expected to take about 5 more years to be commercially available and replace existing methods of making steel.

cards.q: Is there any industry where its use is being tested
cards.a: Yes. The **Volvo** car manufacturing has begun to use it for their *mining and quarrying* vehicle starting Oct-2021

cards.q: Which companies are making green steel today
cards.a: A Swedish industrial consortium have announced the development of a green steel called **Hybrit**

_data.title: What is Highlining
_data.description: Know more about this adventure sport
_data.author: rmr

links.title: Crossing the longest slackline in the world

cards.q: What is **Highlining**
cards.a: It is a form of **adventure sports** where a person balances along a suspended rope

cards.q: Is it like tightrope walking
cards.a: Yes, it is similar but there are differences in the tension of the rope and the material. *Highlining*, in fact,  is a type of **Slacklining**.

cards.q: What is a **Slacklining**
cards.a: The form of sports where the rope is a *flat webbing* of about **1-2 inch** wide that is tensioned between two anchors

cards.q: Is a pole used to balance
cards.a: No. Folks use their **arms and legs to balance** unlike tightrope walkers who use a long pole to balance.

cards.q: Is it called highlining when slacklining is done at a **greater height**
cards.a: Yes. Between two high points, usually across *mountains* or *ridges*, with a deep *valley* below.

cards.q: Is having a good balance a requirement of highlining
cards.a: A **strong mental game and mindset** are far more important than the technical and physical ability. It requires *concentration*, *focus* and *immense practice* to perform this walk.

cards.q: How is practice done
cards.a: In **controlled environments**. One begins at low heights of 2-5 feet across sand pit or soft ground. Then, one progresses to greater heights with no soft ground at the same time building mental ability.

cards.q: Don't the participants wear protective gear
cards.a: Yes. They do wear a **harness**. There are two ropes. One is the tensioned one called **main slackline** on which one balances oneself. There is a second *slackened* rope which serves as a backup in case the main rope breaks or tears called the **backup** slackline. The harness is attached to both these lines.

cards.q: How long is a typical highline walk
cards.a: It varies usually ranging from 500m to a couple of kms and can take an hour or so.

cards.q: What is the longest slackline record
Do highliners walk **blindfolded** too
cards.a: Yes. Recently on 30-Nov-2021, **Alexander Shultz**, walked a length of **1712 m** at an approx height of **700m** blindfolded in a duration of **1h 15m**.

_data.title: What is Holoportation
_data.description: Understand this amazing technology
_data.author: nanc

cards.q: What is **Holoportation**
cards.a: It is a new type of 3D capture technology that allows high-quality 3D models to be reconstructed, compressed and transmitted anywhere in real time

cards.q: Is it a form of **Teleportation**
cards.a:
Yes, the word is a combination of **Holography** and **Teleportation** i.e. use of Holography for Teleportation needs.
 
> **Teleportation** is the hypothetical transfer of matter or energy from one point to another 
> **Holography** is a technique to generate 3-dimensional images to be recorded and later re-constructed

cards.q: What can one do with Holoportation
What is required for Holoportation to work
cards.a: It requires **3d capture technology** and **mixed reality headsets**

cards.q: What do we mean by 3d capture technology
What are the type of headsets required for this technology
cards.a: **Head Mounted Display** (HMD) like the *Hololens* and *HTC Vive*. These are similar to VR headsets.

cards.q: What sort of bandwidth is required for this technology to work
cards.a: When the invention began it required very high bandwidths that was possible only in labs. Now it has been reduced to 30-50 Mbps and works over regular WiFi networks.

cards.q: Is it similar to VR
cards.a: No. In VR, all the participants are *transported* to a digital space where they meet one another as **avatars**. In Holoportation, the remote participants *seem to appear* in **your physical space** (as seen through the headset).

cards.q: What are the uses of Holoportation
cards.a: **Education** would be a big beneficiary as would other requirements of presence of people without travel. **Training** is another big area of the use of such a technology.

cards.q: Who invented Holoportation
cards.a: Microsoft

cards.q: When was it launched
cards.a: It was first demonstrated in 2016

cards.q: Is it commercially available
cards.a: Not yet due to its high cost. However, some government departments have begun experimenting with it.

cards.q: Has there been a practical use-case of it
cards.a: In Oct-2021, astronaut *Thomas Pesquet* onboard the **International Space Station** (ISS) interacted with NASAs flight surgeon, *Dr Josef Schmidt* while he was on **Earth**. This triggered much interest in the technology.

_data.title: What is Hydroponics
_data.description: Know more of its use
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Hydroponics
cards.a: It is a type of **soilless** method of growing plants in an *aqueous solvent* with nutrients

cards.q: Is it the same as Soilless gardening
How does the system work
cards.a: It is best explained by this diagram

cards.q: Which types of vegetables are popularly grown using Hydroponics
cards.a:
1. Lettuce and other greens, like spinach and kale
2. Tomatoes
3. Cucumbers
4. Green Beans
5. Basil

cards.q: In what way is growing using Hydroponics better than using soil
Do hydroponic plants taste differently
cards.a: Yes. But then even plants grown on different soils taste different!

cards.q: What are the nutrients required for these plants
cards.a:
All plants basically need the same 5 key nutrients: 
- nitrogen
- phosphorous
- potassium
- calcium
- magnesium
 
> some plants may require more of one nutrient than another

cards.q: Can regular fertilisers be used for hydroponic plants
cards.a: Yes, but not recommended. Special nutrients are available that ensure the right concentration required for growth.

cards.q: Is sunlight required for hydroponic plants
Are hydroponic sprouts more nutritious than its soil equivalents
In general are hydroponically grown vegetables more nutritious than soil grown vegetables
cards.a: Hydroponics gives the growers the ability to **control** the nutrients. Hence, it would be right to say that the vegetables that grow from this process would be more nutritious ... unless less care has been taken!

cards.q: Is it true that hydroponically grown tomatoes are tasteless
cards.a: The method usually produces tomatoes that are big and juicy tomatoes viz. has more water and cellulose, and less flavor per bite

cards.q: Are there plants that cannot be grown hydroponically
cards.a:
Yes. Mostly root plants which require plenty of soils to spread their roots in search of moisture and nutrients. Such as:
- turnips
- onions
- garlic
- carrots

cards.q: Are hydroponic systems like fish tanks that need to replinish their water periodically
cards.a: Yes. Depending on the size, water and nutrients are re-calibrated to ensure that the right level of nutrients exist in the water. This is done every two or three weeks

cards.q: So, what are the advantages of Hydroponics
cards.a:
1. Better control of nutrients and hence more efficient
2. Plants can be grown outside of fields viz. at homes too
3. There is option to grow vertically which the regular soil based agriculture does not offer
 
> a separate deck on vertical gardening will be available shortly

cards.q: And, what are the disadvantages of Hydroponics
cards.a:
A hydroponic system:
- can be costly in comparison to traditional soil based horticulture
- requires more monitoring
- vulnerable to power outages *in those systems that use power*

_data.title: What is Hyperloop
_data.description: Is this the future of transport
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Hyperloop
cards.a: A new high speed mode of transport on ground for passenger and freight

cards.q: How is it different from road and rail transport
cards.a: Passenger *pods* or cargo *pods* travel through *tubes* at very high speed

cards.q: What is a Pod
cards.a: Think of it as a compartment specially designed for hyperloop technology

cards.q: What are the speeds at which these pods move
cards.a: Reaching speeds above 600 kmph! ... the technology promises to reach over 1000 kmph

cards.q: How do Hyperloops work
cards.a:
1. Tubes are laid out between pod terminals
2. The air within the tube is sucked out to provide a frictionless movement of the pods
3. The pods accelerate using electric propulsion
4. The pods floats in the tube using magnetic levitation and guides

cards.q: How many passengers can travel in a pod
cards.a: Depends on the pod. Current tests have shown seating capacity of 20 to 40 passengers

cards.q: Do passengers feel uncomfortable during travel
cards.a: Not as per test reports. Passengers feel *stronger than* when one takes off in a plane but not discomforting as reported.

cards.q: What are the advantages of Hyperloop technology
cards.a:
1. Transportation will be faster
2. It is supposed to be built quicker and cheaper than rail infrastructure

cards.q: Is Hyperloop tunnel always built below the ground
cards.a: No. The technology is independent of below or over land. However, at times it may be easier to bore a tunnel below land to overcome challenges of creating a path.

cards.q: What is the diameter of the tunnel
cards.a: In some of the proof of concept runs, the tunnels have been between 3 and 4 metres

cards.q: Which are the companies developing Hyperloop travel infrastructure
cards.a:
1. The Boring Company
2. Virgin Hyperloop
3. Hyperloop Transportation
4. Transpod

cards.q: Has any company started Hyperloop operations
cards.a: No. It has not yet been commercially launched.

cards.q: Has any test being conducted with passengers
cards.a:
Yes. Virgin Hyperloop were the first to conduct a test with human passengers.
- on 8-Nov-2020
- on a 500m track in Nevada, US
- took 15 seconds
- reached speed of 172 km/h or 107 mph
- passengers
  - Lara Luchian and Josh Giegel 
  - Tanay Manjrekar and Anne Huynh

cards.q: Which are some of the Hyperloop projects underway
cards.a:
1. 2km *proof of concept* in **Hawthorne** in Los Angeles county, US
2. 48 kms between cities **Mumbai and Pune** of India
3. 690 km between **Dallas and Laredo** in Texas, US
4. 951 km between **Jeddah and Riyadh** in Saudi Arabia

cards.q: Who conceived of the Hyperloop
cards.a: There has been some mention of a similar technology by an inventor named **George Medhurst** in 1799

cards.q: Why is Elon Musk being credited with the Hyperloop
cards.a: Because, Elon Musk reignited interest with his *Hyperloop Alpha* paper in August 2013, which set out how a modern system would work and how much it would cost

_data.title: What is LIDAR
_data.description: A simple understanding of its working
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of LIDAR
cards.a: Light Detection and Ranging

cards.q: So what is LIDAR used for
cards.a: It is used to measure distance between two objects

cards.q: How does it work
cards.a:
1. A Lidar sensor emits light waves from a **laser** into the environment 
2. These pulses **bounce off** surrounding objects and return to the sensor
3. The sensor uses the **time** it took for each pulse to return to the sensor to calculate the distance it traveled

cards.q: What is a Laser
Is LIDAR similar to RADAR
What about SONAR, is LIDAR similar to it
Is Lidar better than Radar and Sonar
cards.a: LiDAR uses lasers with a much lower wavelength than the radio waves used by RADAR. Thanks to this, LiDAR has better accuracy and precision, which allows it to detect smaller objects and create 3D models.

cards.q: How is the 3D model creation helpful
cards.a: It can be used to now predict whether the object is, say, a **tree**, **person** or a **wall**

cards.q: Why has Lidar become popular
cards.a: Because it is an important component of self-driving cars

cards.q: How is Lidar used in cars
cards.a: Autonomous cars usually have a unit on its roof that houses the Lidar unit. It continuously emits pulses to determine all the objects relative to the position of the car in 3D.

cards.q: How **small** an object can a Lidar placed on a car see
cards.a: Tests have shown that they can detect even the hand signal given by a cyclist!

cards.q: Can Lidar *see through* walls
cards.a: No. The pulses emitted by the laser will bounce off the wall

cards.q: Which are some of the other applications where Lidar is being used
cards.a:
1. **Agriculture**: It can reveal topography including fields, slopes, farmland etc
2. **Mining**: To evaluate periodic scans of ore removal
3. **Surveying**: Flights fitted with Lidars can quickly scan vast areas

cards.q: What are the disadvantages of using Lidar
cards.a:
1. Its high cost
2. Its inability to measure distance through heavy rain, snow, and fog

_data.title: What is LiFi
_data.description: Is this an advanced form of WiFI?
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of LiFi
cards.a: Light Fidelity

cards.q: Is it like WiFi
cards.a: Yes, except that the technology used Light to transfer data

cards.q: Just like WiFi is it a sort of communication
cards.a: Yes! It is a wireless communication that aims to use light to transmit information from point A to point B

cards.q: How does it work
cards.a: The technology works by encoding digital data and turning LED bulbs on and off faster than humans can notice to transfer it. The light then travels to a photoreceptor, which can decode and translate the data to a more classic radio frequency (WiFi, or 4G or 5G).

cards.q: Is the transmission of data faster
cards.a: Yes, its theroretical speeds are aboput 100Gbit/s, more than 5 times faster than WiFi (5G)

cards.q: How is WiFi wireless different from LiFi wireless
cards.a: WiFi uses radio frequencies while LiFi uses visible, ultraviolet, and infrared light frequencies

cards.q: In what way is it different from WiFi
cards.a:
1. LiFi is based on light frequency while WiFi is based on radio frequency
2. The light source and receptor should be in close proximity unlike WiFi, which can pass through walls
3. LiFi range is much more limited than WiFi
4. Chances of interference is more in LiFi over WiFi

cards.q: Since LiFi can connect devices within the same room is it not limiting
cards.a: Yes. But the silver lining is that people cannot stealthily piggy back on a connection

cards.q: Is it similar to Fibre Optics
cards.a: Yes, in the sense that the fibre optic cables uses light to transmit data. But LiFi is a wireless communication.

cards.q: Are there applications where it would be better suited over WiFi
cards.a: Yes, in **electromagnetic sensitive areas** such as in aircraft cabins, hospitals and nuclear power plants where data transfer can be done without causing electromagnetic interference

cards.q: One hears of **spectrum crisis** in the context of Wireless data. Will that change with LiFi
cards.a: Yes. WiFi uses radio frequencies which are close to full capacity, LiFi on the other hand uses visible light frequencies which are 10,000 times larger than radio waves

cards.q: Who coined the word LiFi
cards.a: Harald Haas coined during a TED talk in 2011

cards.q: Is it commercically being used
cards.a: Not yet. Technology is being perfected and prices of photoreceptors need to come down to make it commercially viable.

_data.title: What is LTO
_data.description: Know more about this tape storage technology
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of LTO
cards.a: **Linear Tape-Open** Technology

cards.q: Is it a technology to store data on tapes
cards.a: Yes. It is an **open** format technology for *tape storage solutions*

cards.q: Is not tape storage ancient and not used popularly today
What is tape storage used for in today's cloud environments
cards.a: As a **backup** that should not be available online

cards.q: Why is tape storage still preferred as a backup medium
cards.a:
1. **Lower costs** that other storage solutions
2. Being an **offline** medium, it can be stored behind an *air gap* out of reach of criminals
3. It has the **least error rate** amongst all data storage mediums
4. It can **quickly** be restored to online media

cards.q: How much of a cost savings does it offer
cards.a: Estimates made over a 10 year period show that LTO technology is **86%** lower than all-disk solutions and **66%** lower than cloud storage solutions

cards.q: What is the life-span of a LTO tape
cards.a: It is usually quoted to be **30 years**

cards.q: What is the format in which the data is stored
cards.a: The format is called **Ultrium** and uses a single-reel cartridge to store data

cards.q: What is the storage capacity of a LTO tape
What is the size of these tapes
Does LTO support encryption
cards.a: Yes. LTO drives use the **256-bit AES** (Advanced Encryption Standard).

cards.q: Is the LTO technology improving over time
If the version changes would it not cause problems to restore the data
What is an **open-tape format** specification
Which companies are making LTO tapes
cards.a: **Hewlett-Packard**, **IBM** and **Quantum**

_data.title: What is Metaverse
_data.description: Know more about the latest buzzword in technology
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: How to describe Metaverse in a single sentence
cards.a: It is a 3D virtual world accessible via internet

cards.q: What can be done in Metaverse
cards.a:
1. Play games on a virtual playground or arena
2. Learn in a virtual classroom
3. Train to operate virtual machines
4. Just hang around in an area and socialise with people
5. Buy property!

cards.q: Who coined the word
cards.a: It was first described in the 1992 novel **Snow Crash** by Neal Stephenson

cards.q: When did it all start
cards.a: Technology is usually built bit by bit and Metaverse is no different. Virtual online communities were built in the early 2000s. *Second Life* in 2003 being one of the most popular.

cards.q: Why is Metaverse getting popular now
cards.a:
Time is ripe due to progress in:
- 5G networks
- more computing power and memory in small devices
- coming of age of and VR and AR
- need to work remotely

cards.q: Do we need special equipment to participate in Metaverse
cards.a:
1. A desktop or notebook computer
2. A Virtual Reality (VR) headset for an immersive experience
3. Tactile Gloves will help feel objects in this  world
4. Wrist sensors to feel sensation (e.g. *Bow & Arrow games*) 
5. Augmented Reality (AR) Glasses to interact with objects

cards.q: Do I need to walk at home to move in the virtual world
cards.a:
No! That would be disastrous. There are a number of ways this is accomplished
1. Using the keyboard one can move in two directions
2. People wear a harness around them and walk like in a treadmill
3. In some cases, you may just point to a place and you get *teleported* there

cards.q: How would we use the keyboard to move
cards.a:
For example:
1. Moving the up and down arrow takes you forward or backward
2. Similarly the left and right arrow moves you left or right
3. Perhaps, a shift + left will turn your view to the left

While keyboard equivalents are available, having a VR headset makes the experience immersive.

cards.q: How do we focus or point to an object
cards.a:
Just like we have a cursor on a normal computer, so is the case in a Metaverse world. 
1. The cursor can be pointed to an object and clicked to select via a mouse.
2. Or if one uses a headset, then we turn in the desired direction and position the cursor on that object and tap on a button on the side of the headset.

cards.q: Can we move objects in Metaverse
cards.a: Yes, this is much like in the physical world, where using the hand gloves, you could touch objects, move them, lift them and place them elsewhere

cards.q: What are **Hand Gloves**
cards.a: These are electronic gloves with controllers that are connected to the headset so that movement of one's hands get translated to gestures in the virtual world

cards.q: Is it similar to the purpose of joy sticks in gaming
cards.a: Yes. These versatile hand controllers can be used in 3D environments.

cards.q: Can we speak to others in Metaverse
Then, how is it different from video conferencing
cards.a: It is 3D and the experience gives you a feeling of being in the other place

cards.q: Can we see the other person like we do in a video
cards.a: No. Everyone is represented by an **avatar**. Though many create avatars which have a resemblance to their own self.

cards.q: How are avatars created similar to oneself
cards.a: Avatar creation softwares are available that take a bunch of snaps from different positions or using a camera to create an avatar. These avatars have a fair resemblance to the person. Once made, it can be kept as an indentity for all worlds.

cards.q: Would not people make avatars that are different from how they look
cards.a: Yes. And very often that is the case. In fact, one of the likely reasons for its popularity is that a person can be a very **different** one in this virtual world.

cards.q: Why are people buying space in Metaverse worlds
cards.a:
All real estate investments are for two purposes:
1. To stay or enjoy the property
2. As investment to sell it when it appreciates      

In the case of Metaverse, it is often the latter.

cards.q: Is VR experiences similar to the **Real Player One** movie
cards.a: Yes. The movie which was based on the book by *Ernest Cline* explored how people escape the problems of earth by going into a virtual world ... except a movie is a movie!

_data.title: What is Monkeypox
_data.description: Know more about this disease
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Monkeypox**
cards.a: It is a viral **zoonosis** with symptoms similar to *smallpox*

cards.q: What is a viral **Zoonosis**
cards.a: A virus transmitted to **humans from animals**

cards.q: What are the symptoms of monkeypox
cards.a:
- high **fever**
- intense **headache**
- **rashes**
- swollen **lymph nodes**

cards.q: Why is it called *monkeypox*
cards.a: Because it was first discovered in 1958 when two outbreaks of a pox-like disease occurred in **colonies of monkeys** kept for research

cards.q: In which part of the world does this primarily occur
cards.a: In tropical rainforests of **Central and West Africa**, even though it can spread to other regions

cards.q: Why is it in news now
cards.a: There has been incidents of its occurence in other parts of the world, especially Europe, US, Canada and Australia

cards.q: Is monkeypox fatal
Is there a cure for monkeypox
cards.a: There is no proven safe cure for monkeypox. Though **antivirals** and **smallpox vaccines** are used to limit its spread.

cards.q: Is not smallpox eradicated in the world
cards.a: Yes, since **May 1980** smallpox has been eradicated from the world

cards.q: How does monkeypox get transmitted from animals to humans
cards.a: It can occur from direct contact with the **blood**, **bodily fluids**, or **cutaneous or mucosal lesions** of infected animals

cards.q: How is the monkeypox transmitted between humans
cards.a:
By close contact with :
- **lesions**
- body **fluids**
- **respiratory droplets** and **bleeding**

cards.q: What is the **incubation period** of monkeypox
cards.a: Usually 6 to 12 days

cards.q: When was it first identified in humans
cards.a: In **1970** in the Democratic Republic of the **Congo** in a 9-year-old boy in a region where smallpox had been eliminated in 1968

_data.title: What is Meme
_data.description: A non-technical understanding
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is a Meme
cards.a: It is  is an idea, behavior, image, or style that is spread through social media platforms

cards.q: How is it pronounced
cards.a: /miːm/ MEEM

cards.q: In what digital forms are Meems
cards.a: Usually Photos or Videos, though it can be a block of text

cards.q: What is an example of a Meme
Who coined the word: Meme
cards.a: It is credited to evolutionary biologist **Richard Dawkins** who referred to it in his book, *The Selfish Gene* (1976) who described it as *an idea, behavior, or style that rapidly spreads from person to person in a culture*

cards.q: Why do people Meem
cards.a:
- to be funny or humourous
- to be sarcastic
- to teach a life lesson
- to be shocking

cards.q: Do companies too *meme* or just individuals
cards.a:
Companies do meme and it could be for one of many reasons:
- to share info in a fun format
- to humanise the brand
- for higher engagement with the audience
- to demonstrate some complicated concept

_data.title: What is NFT
_data.description: An overview for everyone
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of NFT
cards.a:
**Non-fungible Token**

- Non-fungible: meaning that it is *unique* and *cannot be changed*
- Token is a *representation* of something and in this case it is a digital token

In short, NFT is a digital representation of something that is unique and cannot change.

cards.q: What are some of the examples of things that can be NFTs
cards.a:
1. Artworks
2. Music, Videos
3. Memorabilia, Collectibles
4. Tweets
5. Alcohol (Yes!)
6. Source code (programs)
7. Virtual real estate

Almost anything.

cards.q: Does the NFT contain the digital item or asset?
cards.a: No. Again the NFT is a representation of the item, whether it is physical or digital

cards.q: How can NFTs be offered for physical items?
cards.a: Remember an NFT is a **representation** for something, which can be a physical item too

cards.q: What do we mean by representation of an item
cards.a: Think of how a *library card* in a physical Library is a representation of the physical book that is stored on the shelf

cards.q: Does that mean that the asset, digital or physical, is stored elsewhere
Does the owner of an NFT get copyright to the underlying asset
Does this mean that an artwork (digital or otherwise) can be owned by several people
It looks like there can be different terms in which an NFT can be sold. Right?
cards.a: Yes, the terms of the NFT are specified and part of the NFT

cards.q: Why would someone buy an NFT
cards.a: Because it is of some value to them and in most cases it's value, they believe, would appreciate over time. Just like *any other asset*.

cards.q: Why would a creator sell an NFT
cards.a: It is another medium to sell something someone has created

cards.q: Why would someone sell an item as a NFT instead of using shops or auction houses or brokers
Do physical goods bought get sent to the buyer
Does owning a NFT give the buyer exclusive access to the asset
Would this not diminish the value of the asset
Which was the first NFT that was sold by a major auction house
cards.a:
A digital artwork called **Everydays: The First 5000 Days** by Beeple.

1. This is a collage of 5000 digital images created by Mike Winkelmann (Beeple) 
2. This was sold for USD 69 million.

cards.q: What are some of the popular NFTs that have been sold
cards.a:
1. Beeple's "Everydays: The First 5000 Days"
2. Jack Dorsey first tweet
3. Distillers William Grant and Son sold 15 bottles of 46-year-old Glenfiddich whisky for $18,000 a piece
4. NBA shots sports collectibles
5. This Changed Everything is an NFT of the source code used for one of the earliest versions of the World Wide Web sold for USD 5.4 million

cards.q: What is **The Merge**
cards.a:
1. The Merge is a digital artwork created by an anonymous digital artist nicknamed *Pak*
2. It was sold on Dec. 6, 2021 for $91.8 million
3. The piece was fractionalized to 312,686 pieces distributed to 28,983 buyers
4. The Merge was a single artwork composed of a collection of **masses** that users could buy
5. These pieces could be *stockpiled* to make a bigger mass and sell it on the secondary market

_data.title: QUAD
_data.description: An overview of the QUAD dialog
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is QUAD an abbreviation of
cards.a: The Quadrilateral Security Dialogue

cards.q: QUAD is a dialogue between which countries
cards.a:
It is a strategic security dialogue between:
- Australia 
- India
- Japan
- USA

cards.q: What was the objective of QUAD
cards.a: to work for a free, open, prosperous and inclusive Indo-Pacific region

cards.q: When was QUAD initiated
cards.a: In **2007** by the then Japanese Prime Minister *Shinzo Abe*

cards.q: If it was initiated so many years back, why the sudden interest in 2020s
cards.a:
- In 2008 Australia terminated the quadrilateral causing a lull
- In 2017 Japan invited the member countries reinvigorating the quadrilateral
- Changes in geo-politics esp with China's *Belt and Roat initiative* added the right fuel

cards.q: Why is it viewed as an anti-Chinese
Is Quad a military alliance
cards.a: No. In the words of the foreign ministers of the Quad countries, it is *to reaffirm shared commitment to rules-based order in the Indo-Pacific region*.

cards.q: When was the first Quad Summit held
cards.a: In March 2021, US President Joe Biden hosted a *virtual summit*

cards.q: Is Quad like an Asian NATO
What are some of the other areas that are jointly being worked upon
cards.a:
- Anti-covid vaccine distribution
- Supply Chain availability  
- Climate Control
- Education

_data.title: Robotic Surgery
_data.description: Will Robotic Surgeries help patients?
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Robotic Surgery
cards.a: They are types of surgeries that are done using robotic systems

cards.q: Are Robotic Surgeries done by machines
cards.a: No. They assist surgeons in performing complicated and delicate surgeries

cards.q: What are common Robotic Surgeries
cards.a:
1. Gynecologic Surgery
2. Prostate Surgery
3. Head and Neck Surgery
4. Gastrointestinal Surgery
5. Heart Surgery

cards.q: What are the benefits of such surgeries
cards.a:
- Surgeons get better view of what is happening
- Reduced pain and discomfort
- Faster recovery time 
- Smaller incisions hence reduced risk of infection
- Reduced blood loss and transfusions

cards.q: Are these surgeries safe
cards.a: Robotic surgery involves risk - *similar to those of conventional open surgery* -  such as a small risk of infection and other complications

cards.q: In what way do these robots help doctors perform surgery
cards.a: Doctors can now perform many types of complex procedures with more **precision**, **flexibility** and **control** than is possible with conventional techniques

cards.q: What are the parts of a surgical robot
cards.a:
1. Surgeon's console
2. Patient cart
3. Vision cart

cards.q: What is in the **Surgeon's console**
cards.a:
The console is the place where the surgeon:
- sits and sees what is happening
- has master control of how the instruments need to move
- can view high-definition real-time 3D images

cards.q: What is in the **Patient cart**
cards.a:
The Patient cart:
- is kept next to the patient’s bed
- holds the camera and the instruments that are required for the surgery

cards.q: What is in the **Vision cart**
cards.a: The Vision cart is in charge of enabling the communication to take place seamlessly between all the components

cards.q: Which is the most popular Surgical Robotic System
cards.a: The Da Vinci System

cards.q: When was Robotic Surgeries first done
cards.a: in the 1980s

cards.q: Can any surgeon perform robotic surgery
cards.a: With proper training

cards.q: Can robotic surgery be performed remotely
cards.a: Yes. It is also referred to as **Telesurgery**

cards.q: When was the first telesurgery done
cards.a:
The first telesurgery was:
- performed by Professor Jacques Marescaux on 7-Sep-2001 
- performed in Strasbourg, France
- called the **Lindbergh Operation** 
- a telesurgery-assisted *cholecystectomy*
- completed in 54 minutes

_data.title: What is Robotic Process Automation
_data.description: A non-technical explanation
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What do we mean by **Robotic Process Automation**
cards.a: **RPA** is a *business process automation* technology based on bots

cards.q: What is a **bot**
cards.a: Bot or software ro**bot** are software programs that are tasked to do certain tasks in an **automated** manner viz. without human intervention

cards.q: What is an example of a RPA process
cards.a: Companies which require employees to submit expense reports in spreadsheets would be an ideal candidate for a RPA process, which could automatically pick relevant information from cells of the spreadsheet and update the internal expenese management application. This is in lieu of someone doing the task manually.

cards.q: What types of processes are suitable as a RPA process
cards.a: Anything that is routine, repetitive and highly manual

cards.q: Which are the areas in which RPA processes have successful been used
cards.a:
- Banking and Finance processes
- Mortgage and Lending process
- Customer Care automation
- eCommerce merchandising
- data extraction from various sources

cards.q: What are the benefits of RPA
cards.a:
- reduced cost
- increased speed
- higher accuracy and consistency
- improved quality
- scalability of production

cards.q: Is *screen scrapping* a type of RPA process
cards.a: Yes. In the early days of RPA, information was *culled* from screens which were *inputted* into backend systems for further processing. Since then, RPAs have got a lot more sophisticated.

cards.q: Is a chatbot an example of RPA
cards.a: While chatbots are automated processing, it is not considered a RPA since chatbots *interface with a customer*, while RPAs are usually **used by company staff**

cards.q: Is AI and ML part of RPA
cards.a: Yes. Depending on what the repetitive task is, if there is an opportunity to apply machine learning algorithms to process the information, it would be an added advantage.

cards.q: When did the word get coined RPA
cards.a: Around **2012**

cards.q: What are the disdvantages of RPA
cards.a:
- It may increase unemployment
- Some tasks are too complex to be implemented using RPA
- Often, there is no innovative thinking in the process
- Any change in the process requires reconfiguration

_data.title: What is Self Awareness
_data.description: Know more about it
_data.author: nanc

cards.q: What is **Self Awareness**
cards.a:
It is **recognising** and **understanding** of ourselves involving knowing of our:
- character 
- strengths
- weaknesses 
- desires
- dislikes 
- feelings
- emotions

cards.q: Why is self awareness important
cards.a:
Knowing oneself helps in:
- effective communication
- building & sustaining healthy relationships 
- developing empathy for others
 
> It is called the *Mother of all Life Skills*

cards.q: Is *Self Concept* same as *Self Awareness*
cards.a: **Self Concept** is understanding of *I* and *Me* and **Self Awareness** is being aware of one's self concept

cards.q: Does being self aware involve knowing of our imperfections too
cards.a: Yes. Self Awareness is knowing ourselves and our personality & **accepting oneself** in spite of our imperfections

cards.q: How does being self aware help us
cards.a:
It implies that one has:
- **control over**
- **choice of**
- **responsibility for** 
one's *feelings*, *behavior* and *actions* to improve oneself

cards.q: What does being self aware imply
cards.a:
It implies that:
- one knows what (s)he does
- how (s)he does it
- what options and alternatives are available
- how (s)he chooses to be the way (s)he is

cards.q: Are there different components of Self Awareness
cards.a:
Yes there are 3 components of Self Awareness:
1. Cognitive 
2. Affective 
3. Behavioral

cards.q: What is the Cognitive component
cards.a: The understanding that **what I do will influence my thoughts**, is the cognitive or intellectual component of self awareness

cards.q: What is the Affective component
cards.a: The understanding that **what I do will influence my feelings**, is the affective component

cards.q: What is the Behavioral component
cards.a: The understanding that **what I do will influence my behaviour** is the behavior component

cards.q: Is self awareness only about ourselves
cards.a: It is not only about understanding ourselves but also how others feel about us

cards.q: How does knowing how others feel help us
cards.a: Feedback from others about one self is an important part which helps an individual understand oneself in totality

cards.q: Is there any concept to help understand oneself
cards.a:
One of the popular conception of self defined by **Carl Rogers** who said that 
"*It is like 3 sides of a triangle composed of*":
1. **The Perceived Self**: how a person sees self and how others see the person
2. **The Real Self**:  how a person really is
3. **The Ideal Self**: how a person would like to be

cards.q: Is there any techniques to understand oneself better
cards.a:
Yes, two very popular techniques used are:
1. Johari Window
2. SWOT analysis

cards.q: What is Johari Window
cards.a:
It is a 4-parts window model which considers information of what:
1. You and others know about you
2. Only you know about yourself
3. Only others know about you
4. Nobody knows about you

cards.q: What is SWOT Analysis
cards.a:
It is a method to organize your:
- **S**trengths
- **W**eaknesses
- **O**pportunities
- **T**hreats 
giving you a picture of how to play your strengths to manage the challenges.

cards.q: Are there any other aspects important for Self Awareness
cards.a: **Self Esteem** and **Self Confidence**

cards.q: How is Self Esteem different from Self confidence
cards.a: **Self Esteem** refers to how you feel about yourself overall viz. how much positive regard or self love you have

cards.q: What is Self Confidence
Can I increase my Self Esteem & Self Confidence
cards.a: Yes. One of the simplest tool is practicing **positive self-talk**. This works on enhancing both these aspects. Also increase in one helps build the other.

cards.q: What is **positive self-talk**
cards.a:
Positive self-talk involves:
1. Awareness of self-talk
2. Stopping of negative talk 
3. Replacing negative talk with positive talk
4. Stopping of negative thought

_data.title: Sleep Apnea
_data.description: Know more about it
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Sleep Apnea
cards.a: It is a **sleep disorder** in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts

cards.q: What are the symptoms of Sleep Apnea
cards.a:
1. Loud snoring
2. Episodes in which one stops breathing during sleep
3. Gasping for air during sleep
4. Awakening with a dry mouth
5. Morning headache
6. Difficulty staying asleep
7. Dozing off while working

cards.q: Are there types of Sleep Apnea
cards.a:
Yes, there are 3 types:
1.  **Obstructive sleep apnea**, that occurs when throat muscles relax
2. **Central sleep apnea**, which occurs when your brain doesn't send proper signals to the muscles that control breathing
3. **Complex sleep apnea syndrome**, which occurs when someone has both obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea

cards.q: Which is the most common type of sleep apnea
cards.a: The **Obstructive** Sleep Apnea

cards.q: What happens in the Obstructive sleep apnea
cards.a: When the muscles in the back of your throat relax, your airway narrows or closes as you breathe in. You can't get enough air, thereby lowering the oxygen level in your blood. Your brain senses your inability to breathe and briefly rouses you from sleep so that you can reopen your airway.

cards.q: Does this cause one to choke or gasp for breath
cards.a: Yes. This is often reported by the sleeping partner since the patient does not recall it.

cards.q: How often does this narrowing of airways take place during the sleep
cards.a: Studies have indicated that it can be anytime from 5 to 30 times

cards.q: What are the causes of Sleep Apnea
cards.a:
1. **Excess Weight**: obesity greatly increases the risk
2. **Neck circumference**: those with thinner neck have narrower airways
3. **Narrowed airway**: either due to inheritance or due to tonsils etc
4. **Being Male**: men are 2-3 times more prone
5. **Smokers**: have 3 times more probability to develop this condition

cards.q: How does one diagnose this condition
cards.a: Ususally begins with the sleep partner detecting the symptoms which will follow a checkup with a doctor

cards.q: Are there any tests that can be done to confirm the condition
Is there any cure for Sleep Apnea
How does the CPAP machine work
cards.a:
1. A CPAP machine generates a continuous stream of pressurized air that travels through a mask that’s sealed around your nose or mouth delivering purified air.
2. As you sleep, the airstream now pushes against any blockages, opening your airways so your lungs receive plenty of oxygen.
3. Without anything obstructing this flow of oxygen, your breathing doesn’t pause giving you a restful night.

cards.q: Is there a similar machine called BiPAP
cards.a: Yes, it refers to **Bilevel or two-level Positive Airway Pressure**. While CPAP generally delivers a *single pressure*, BiPAP delivers two: an **inhale** pressure and an **exhale** pressure.

_data.title: What is Synaesthesia
_data.description: Know more about this condition
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Synaesthesia**
cards.a: Synaesthesia is a **neurological trait** or condition that results in a joining or **merging of senses** that aren't normally connected

cards.q: What is an example of Synaesthesia
cards.a: A person can **see colors** when *music is being played*

cards.q: Is it a common disorder
cards.a: About **4%** of people experience some type of synaesthesia

cards.q: Does the word mean anything
cards.a: It originates from the Greek words: **syn** meaning union and **aesthesis** meaning sensation

cards.q: Does this occur from childhood or does it get developed sometime later
cards.a: It seems to be present from early childhood and present throughout life

cards.q: What are some of the common senses that get affected
cards.a:
1. Seeing letters or numbers when playing music
2. Feeling a taste when they see words and seeing words while tasting
3. Hearing voices when reading words
4. Feeling sensations when listening to music

cards.q: Is it harmful
cards.a: No. It is not considered an illness. Just a condition.

cards.q: Are there any benefits of having Synaesthesia
cards.a:
1. Some folks enjoy creative activities more
2. Some seem to remember better: equations, vocabulary and facts
3. Some have cognitive abilties being maintained for a longer period of life

cards.q: Were scientific methods used to determine why it occurs
cards.a: Yes. MRI scans of the brain have shown that those with Synaesthesia have more **grey  matter** in regions responsible for perception and attention

cards.q: When was Synaesthesia discovered
cards.a: One of the earliest documented writings was that of **Georg Tobias Ludwig Sachs**, an Austrian Physician, of his own experiences in **1812**

cards.q: Is it genetic
cards.a: Yes. In the sense that it is found in *clusters of families* though scientists have not yet found a particular gene that is responsible for it.

_data.title: What is Tomato Flu
_data.description: Know more about its symptoms and causes
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Tomato Flu**
cards.a: It is a type of viral fever that recently showed up in the southern state of *Kerala in India*

cards.q: What are the symptoms of this flu
cards.a:
- large **rashes**
- skin **irritation**
- high **fever**
- **joints pain**
- severe **dehydration**
- **nausea** and vomitting

cards.q: Why is it called tomato flu
cards.a: Because the rashes are **spherical** in shape, **red** in color and of a size similar to a *tomato*

cards.q: What are the causes of tomato flu
cards.a: That has not been known as yet

cards.q: Is it contagious
cards.a: Yes. People who contract it must be kept away from others

cards.q: Who usually are prone to contract this flu
cards.a: It seems to mainly affect children **under the age of 5**

cards.q: Is it fatal
cards.a: **No**. However, the flu causes severe rashes and at times the boils are large in size with fluid in them. People need to be cautious to prevent spreading of the flu since it is contagious.

cards.q: Are there any medicines to be given to recover from this flu
Is any special care recommended for the patients
cards.a:
1. Being a contagious disease, care must be taken to keep the patient **isolated** from others
2. Their clothes and utensils must be **washed separately**
3. **Ample rest** must be provided
4. **Fluids** must be given regularly to prevent dehydration

_data.title: What is Vertical Farming
_data.description: Is it the solution to end hunger
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Vertical Farming**
cards.a: It is the practice of growing crops in **vertical stacks**

cards.q: Why was vertifical farming thought of
cards.a: With rapid population it is expected that arable land will become *scarce* and vertical farming allows for over **10 times** more yield per acre of land!

cards.q: Who popularised the idea of Vertical Farming
How are crops grown in vertical farms
cards.a: Crops are grown **indoors**, under artificial conditions of light and temperature. It aims at **higher productivity** in smaller spaces using soil-less methods such as *hydroponics, aquaponics* and *aeroponics*.

cards.q: What is **Hydroponics**
cards.a: It is a method of growing food in **water** using mineral nutrient solutions without soil

cards.q: What is Aquaponics
cards.a: It is the technique of growing plants without soil, to create symbiotic relationships between the plants and the **fish** (referred to as *fish farming*)

cards.q: What is Aeroponics
cards.a: In Aeroponics, there is *no growing medium* and hence, no containers for growing crops. In aeroponics, **mist or nutrient solutions** are used instead of water. As the plants are tied to a support and roots are sprayed with nutrient solution, it requires very less space, very less water and no soil. It was designed by NASA as a way to grow plants in space.

cards.q: Which crops are suitable for vertical farms
cards.a:
1. Greens like: *lettuce, coriander, spinach, basil*
2. Corn
3. Cabbage
4. Okra
5. Sprouts

cards.q: Do vertical farms require less water
What are the disadvantages of vertical farming
cards.a:
1. High initial costs
2. Operation costs higher due to energy requirements
3. Limited crops can be grown
4. Calorie content is lesser than traditional farming
5. Higher skills required since it is new
6. Pollination is more difficult

cards.q: If vertical farming has high energy requirements is it eco-friendly
cards.a: Only if **renewable energy sources** like solar are used

cards.q: When and where was the first commercial vertical farms opened
cards.a: In Singapore in 2012

cards.q: Which countries are practicing vertical farming
cards.a:
- Japan
- China
- Korea
- Singapore
- Thailand
- Denmark
- US
- Germany

_data.title: What is Voice Cloning
_data.description: A non-technical understanding
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Voice Cloning**
cards.a: It is is process in which one uses a computer to **generate the speech** of a real individual, creating a clone of their specific, unique voice **using artificial intelligence**

cards.q: Is this the same as **computer generated** voices
cards.a: No. Computer generated voices, called **Text-to-Speech**, are where a text is provided to a speech engine that can speak the text in a **particular voice**. Unlike voice cloning which sounds as though a specific individual has spoken

cards.q: So how is this cloning done
cards.a: Thanks to the advancement of AI, a person can **train** a system to be able to generate one's voice in a short time. And the more one trains, the better is the quality of the generated voice.

cards.q: How exactly does this work
What are the benefits of voice cloning
cards.a:
1. Increased opportunities for voice artists and celebrities
2. Revive voices from the past to relive historical stories
3. Localise content in voices that people in a region are familiar with
4. People who have lost their voices can still *record* new content from past recordings

cards.q: Would not voice cloning be dangerous like fake news
cards.a: Yes. In the sense that one could **publish** controversial statements purportedly made by a known person. This could trigger backlashes against that person when the person would never have made such a statement.

cards.q: Is it same as **Deep Fake Voice**
cards.a: Yes. **Voice Cloning** is the technology but often given the notorious name *Deep Fake Voice* because the **voice** is fake and generated by a **deep** neural network.

cards.q: What is a **Deep Neural Network**
cards.a: It is a type of Machine Learning Tool to make predictions; in this case predicting how a given text would be spoken by somone.

cards.q: Is Voice cloning same as **Digital cloning**
cards.a: Digital cloning could mean cloning of any digital asset: voice, photos, or videos

cards.q: What has made voice cloning popular now
cards.a:
The availability of:
1. Powerful hardware with cloud computing capabilities to process and render the data
2. Extensive training data of the targetted voice
3. More effective algorithms that uses modern concepts like deep neural networks

_data.title: What is Virtual Reality
_data.description: A non-technical explanation
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of VR
cards.a: Virtual Reality

cards.q: What does VR do
cards.a: VR is the use of computer technology to **simulate a 3D environment**

cards.q: What are some of the examples of VR
cards.a:
1. Virtual tours of places of interest
2. Train soldiers with the use of simulations
3. Educational training from remote locations
4. Architectural walkthru's of places
5. Virtual Shopping

cards.q: What is required to experience VR
cards.a:
1. A VR Headset that provides the immersive experience
2. The headset or mobile placed in it should be connected to the internet
3. Access to the virtual environment that is prepared by someone

cards.q: What is a VR Headset
cards.a: It is a head-worn apparatus that covers one eyes for an **immersive experience**. It is also called *VR Googles*.

cards.q: How does it look
Does a VR headset require a mobile
Which sensors are required for a VR experience
cards.a:
Either from within the headset or via the smartphone, VRs use some combination of:
- accelerometer 
- gyroscope 
- magnetometer
- proximity sensor 

all to detect the user's motion in the virtual world.

cards.q: What is an Accelerometer
cards.a: It is a tool that measures acceleration of the body as the user moves across the virtual world

cards.q: What is a Gyroscope
cards.a: It is a tool to sense angular rotational velocity and acceleration of the body as the user turns

cards.q: What is a Magnetometer
cards.a: It is a tool to detect the relative orientation of your mobile / VR relative to the Earth's magnetic north

cards.q: Do we see other folks in the virtual world
cards.a: Yes. But as **avatars**.

cards.q: What are avatars
cards.a: In VR terms, an avatar is a **3D graphical representation** of a user or the user's character or *persona*

cards.q: Can we turn using VR
cards.a: Yes. It provides a 360 degree view of the virtual world. So turning and moving your head will change the view in all directions.

cards.q: Can we move in the virtual world using VR headset
cards.a: Yes. When viewing through the headset there is a cursor (*much like the cursor of our computer*). Often, placing the cursor ahead and **tapping a button** on the side of the headset *transports* you there.

cards.q: Can we speak to others in the virtual world
cards.a: It depends on how the virtual environment has been prepared; if they enable talking to others in the virtual room, then the **mic** and **speaker** (of the VR or mobile) will be used for communication

cards.q: Who prepares a virtual world
cards.a:
1. The Virtual world is prepared via a software running on some servers
2. The Virtual elements like roads, building, walls, seats etc are needed to be created using computer graphics
3. When we connect to that world (*like visiting a website*) one can move around and explore the world

cards.q: Which companies make VR headsets
cards.a:
Some of the popular names are:
1. Oculus Rift
2. Sony Playstation VR
3. HTC Vive
4. Samsung Gear

_data.title: What is Web 3.0
_data.description: A simple understanding of this term
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: Web 3.0 😳? Did we have a 1.0 and 2.0
cards.a:
Yes. 
**Web 1.0** is termed for the first phase of internet when the protocols were defined and companies started putting up their web sites.
 
**Web 2.0** is termed when folks started using the internet for social media apps like Facebook, Twitter, Instagram etc.

cards.q: So what is new in Web 3.0
cards.a:
It is an idea where the web content is based on:
- **blockchain technology** (*separate deck available*) 
- with **decentralisation servers** 
- and **token-based economics**

It is characterised by users owning the content they create viz. blogs, posts, opinions etc.

cards.q: So how is decentralised servers different from today's web servers
cards.a: Currently all the information is available on a single server (*or server farm*). All owned and controlled by the organisation who set up them up. In Web 3.0, the content will be **distributed on multiple servers** (as per the blockchain technology).

cards.q: And what is the token-based economics mean
cards.a: That the creators of such a system could *offer their content* using crypto coins which users may have to furnish to *gain access* to information.

cards.q: What is wrong with Web 2.0 that needed a change
cards.a:
Some of the ills of the current internet usage are:
1. Thanks to the popularity of social media, big-tech internet companies like Facebook, Google, Twitter have become powerful and have the ability to influence and control people.
2. The privacy of most people using these networks is being compromised.
3. These internet companies are leveraging the content created by news companies and individuals; thereby robbing them of their rightful revenue.

cards.q: Who, then, would run the servers of any Web 3.0 website and why
cards.a: It is in the same manner in which the bitcoin and other blockchain networks work today. A set of *people/organisations* unconnected with one another. Except that they need *financial incentives* to be part of it. And that is provided by the token economics that we spoke about earlier,

cards.q: Are there web 3.0 websites in existence today
cards.a: Tech folks are experimenting with it but none of the popular websites have moved to this proposed idea

cards.q: Are there critics to Web 3.0
cards.a:
There are many who believe that:
- it is not going to be easy to implement a blockchain web
- it still is going to be controlled by the few companies who are controlling the crypto world
- that people in general are not ready for token economics for accessing content

cards.q: What is the economics of current internet
cards.a:
1. Corporations and / or Government set up the infrastructure required to run the internet servers
2. They provide the service usually free or at minimal charges
3. In return they capitalise the usage of their service by advertisements and/or influencing the users

cards.q: How would the decentralised system protect privacy and ownership of content
cards.a:
1. Blockchain distributed systems rely on encryption to prevent stealing of information
2. This encryption also ensures no manipulation of someone else's data
3. The distributed system ensures no unauthorised change to content
4. With no single owner to the networks governments cannot access / request access to this information

cards.q: Is Metaverse part of Web 3.0
cards.a: Folks are suggesting that the access to the Web 3.0 content should be via a Metaverse (*separate deck available*) interface

_data.title: What is Wordle
_data.description: Know more about this popular word game and its history
_data.author: vopani

cards.q: What is Wordle
cards.a: It is a web-based word game where a player has to guess a hidden word

cards.q: What are the rules of Wordle
cards.a:
- The player has six attempts to guess a hidden word
- After each guess, feedback is given to the player in the form of coloured tiles indicating if alphabets matched and/or occupy the correct position
- The player wins if the hidden word is correctly guessed within six attempts, else loses

cards.q: What feedback do the coloured tiles indicate
cards.a:
- An alphabet in a green tile indicates that the alphabet is present in the hidden word and in the correct position
- An alphabet in a yellow tile indicates that the alphabet is present in the hidden word but is in the wrong position
- An alphabet in a grey tile indicates that the alphabet is not present in the hidden word

cards.q: What kind of words are hidden
cards.a: A five-letter valid word in the English language

cards.q: What words can be guessed
cards.a: A player’s guess must be a valid five-letter word in the English language

cards.q: What is the time limit to guess a word
cards.a: There is no time limit to guess a word

cards.q: Is there a fee or subscription to play Wordle
cards.a: Wordle can be played for free

cards.q: How many times can Wordle be played
cards.a: Wordle has one hidden word per day, so it can be played at most once a day

cards.q: Who developed Wordle
cards.a: Josh Wardle developed Wordle, initially for himself and his partner to play, before sharing it publicly

cards.q: When was Wordle released publicly
cards.a: October, 2021

cards.q: Who owns Wordle
cards.a: The New York Times Company purchased Wordle from Josh Wardle on 31st January, 2022

_data.title: Who owns Space
_data.description: Learn the laws that govern space
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: Is there an accepted understanding on who owns space
cards.a: No. However, some laws are in place and with the prospects of **space exploration**, **space tourism** and **space mining** this is bound to change

cards.q: Is there a definition of where **space** begins
cards.a: It is generally accepted that the **Karman Line**, at an altitude of **100 kms (62 mi)**, is accepted as the start of outer space

cards.q: Are there international laws that govern outer space
cards.a:
Yes, there are 5 international treaties in place:
1. **The Outer Space Treaty**
2. **The Rescue Agreement**
3. **The Moon Agreement**
4. **The Liability Convention**
5. **The Registration Convention**

cards.q: Who governs these treaties
cards.a: The United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (**UNCOPUOS**)

cards.q: What are the main principles of **The Outer Space Treaty** (OST)
cards.a:
1. That space activities are for the **benefit** of all countries
2. No nation can **own** space, moon or other bodies
3. **Weapons of Mass Destruction** (WMDs) are forbidden in space and celestial bodies
4. An Astronaut is a **envoy of mankind** and all help must be provided in case of emergency landing
5. Nations are responsible for **damage** caused by their space bodies

cards.q: When was the OST signed and by how many nations
cards.a: The treaty came into force **1967** and as of 2021, 129 nations are committed to this treaty

cards.q: What does **The Rescue Agreement** encompass
cards.a:
The signatories to this agreement confirm:
- that they will help or rescue astronauts and return them to their nation
- that they will return to the sponsoring nation any objects that land on earth

cards.q: What does **The Moon Agreement** state
cards.a:
The Agreement states that: 
1. Celestial bodies can only be used for **peaceful purposes** 
2. They should not be contaminated
3. The UN should always be made aware of any station on a non-Earth body
4. If resource mining on the Moon becomes feasible, an international regime must be established to govern how those resources are obtained and used
 
> Only 11 countries are party to this agreement!

cards.q: What does **The Liability Convention** state
cards.a: That signatories take **full liability** for any damage caused by their space objects and agree to standard procedures for adjudicating damage claims

cards.q: What does **The Registration Convention** state
cards.a: This **empowers** the UN Secretary-General to maintain a register of all space objects

cards.q: What is the consensus about **space mining**
cards.a:
Despite the earlier mentioned treaties there is ambiguity on the interpretation of space mining.
- e.g. In US, they follow the doctrine of *finders, keepers**
- e.g. In Luxembourg, space mining companies can keep their assets
 
> It is also referred to as **asteroid mining**

cards.q: Why would countries want to mine an astroid
cards.a:
1. Because some important resources are becoming scarce on earth
2. Because mining of some of these resources are causing environmental damage on earth
3. Because the resources from astroids can be used to build space infrastructure instead of carrying it from earth

cards.q: What are some of the materials that can be found in Astroids
cards.a:
- Platinium
- Iron
- Nickel
- Gold

cards.q: How does somone mine an astroid
cards.a:
Simply put:
- A manageably small astroid will be chosen
- It will be moved to a place in space where it is easy to process
- It will be taken apart into smaller useful products

cards.q: Would it not be expensive to mine an astroid
cards.a: Yes. At this moment. Futurologists believe with the rise and popularity of space explorations, this could become a viable option in the future

_data.title: World Happiness Report: 2022
_data.description: A brief overview of the report
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What does the World Happiness Report contain
cards.a: The report contains articles and rankings of national happiness, based on people's own assessment of their happiness, as well as other economic and social data

cards.q: Who prepares this report
cards.a: **United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network** publishes this report on a yearly basis

cards.q: What are the key highlights of the 2022 report
cards.a:
1. Ranking of nations by Happiness Index
2. Examination of emotions, behaviour, and life in general during the year
3. The factors that will affect future happiness
4. The relationship between Biology and Happiness
5. The range of emotions that affect happiness

cards.q: Which are the top-5 countries ranked on Happiness Index
cards.a:
From a compiled list of 146 countries, the top 5 are:
1. Finland
2. Denmark
3. Iceland
4. Switzerland
5. Netherlands
 
> This is based on the 3-year average (2019-21)

cards.q: What are considered as **indicators of well-being**
cards.a:
They are: 
- **life evaluations** 
- **positive emotions**
- **negative emotions**

cards.q: How is the poll conducted
cards.a:
1. Respondents are asked to evaluate their current life on a scale of 0 to 10 (*Cantrill ladder*)
2. Weights are used to construct population-representative national averages for each year in each country
3. National rankings are arrived at on a 3-year average
4. At least 1000 respondents are surveyed

cards.q: Which countries fared poorly as per the survey
cards.a:
The bottom five were:
142. Botswana
143. Rwanda
144. Zimbabwe
145. Lebanon
146. Afghanistan

cards.q: Has there been a rise or fall in life satisfaction during the year
cards.a: For the young, life satisfaction has **fallen**, while for those over 60, it has **risen**

cards.q: Has there been an increase in benevolence in 2021
cards.a: In every region, there have been **increases** in the proportion of people who give money to charity, and engage in voluntary work. These have *gone up by a quarter* in 2021, compared with before the pandemic.

cards.q: What are the trends in the conceptions of progress and well-being
cards.a:
1. **Interest** in happiness and subjective well-being has *risen sharply*
2. **Attention** to income and GDP is *decreasing*
3. **Academic research** on happiness has *grown multi-fold*
4. Happiness is **getting added** as one of the *indicators* of Progress
5. Governments are using happiness as a **measure** to *devise policies*

cards.q: What is the role of social media in capturing emotions during the last year
cards.a:
The report compares the effect of covid on social media for this purpose:
1. Millions of people share their thoughts and feelings online via social media each day
2. Twitter data in 18 countries showed strong increases in anxiety and sadness during COVID-19

cards.q: Does genetics play a role in determining one's happiness
cards.a: Yes. Studies reveal that about 30-40% of the differences in happiness between people within a country are accounted for by **genetic differences** between people

cards.q: Does not the environment affect happiness
What is the role of human body processes and chemicals in determining happiness
cards.a:
Some studies done on this reveal: 
1. Higher **positive emotion** is associated with higher levels of serotonin and lower levels of cortisol
2. **Chronic activity** of the immune system is linked to lower well-being

cards.q: Do people prefer a calmer life or an exciting one
cards.a: The majority of people in almost every country prefer **a calmer life** to an exciting one

cards.q: When is the World Happiness Report released each year
cards.a: Normally around the **International Day of Happiness**

cards.q: When is the *International Day of Happiness* celebrated
cards.a: It is celebrated on **20-March** every year

cards.q: When was the International Day of Happiness established
cards.a: The **United Nations** General Assembly established it on **28-June-2012**

cards.q: What is the aim of the Day of Happiness
cards.a: It aims to make people around the world realize the **importance of happiness** within their lives

cards.q: When was the first World Happiness Report released
What is **Gross National Happiness**
Which was the first country that introduced GNH
cards.a: Bhutan as early as 1998

cards.q: Who coined the term Gross National Happiness
cards.a: The term coined by His Majesty the Fourth King of Bhutan, **Jigme Singye Wangchuck** in the 1970s

_data.title: International Women's Day:  8-March
_data.description: Some interesting trivia and history
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: When is International Women's Day (IWD) celebrated
cards.a: 8-March every year

cards.q: For what purpose
cards.a: To celebrate women's achievements in all spheres of life

cards.q: Who started this movement
cards.a: **Clara Zetkin**, who - then - was the leader of the Socialist Party of America

cards.q: When was the first Women's Day celebrated
cards.a: On **28-Feb-1909**, by the Socialist Party of America in New York City

cards.q: What took place at this event
cards.a: About 100 delegates, representing 17 countries, agreed with the idea as a strategy to **promote equal rights**, including women's suffrage

cards.q: Did they declare it to be an annual event then
cards.a: No. Later, the next year in 1910, it was suggested to make it an annual affair though no specific date was decided.

cards.q: When was the first time IWD was celebrated on 8-March
cards.a: In 1914, the IWD in Germany, which was dedicated for women's right to vote, celebrated it on 8-March because it was a convenient date

cards.q: When was the date officially accepted as 8-March
cards.a: In 1975, when UN began celebrating 8-March as International Women's Day

cards.q: What was one of the earliest big wins of IWD
cards.a: In 1917 when the government in Russia permitted women to vote

cards.q: Are there any specific colors associated with IWD
cards.a: Yes. It is **Purple**, along with Green and White

cards.q: Does IWD have a specific symbol
What is special about Mimosa
cards.a: It has a bright yellow tone and is wavy, and spreads out when it blossoms radiating energy and liveliness

cards.q: Does IWD have a theme
cards.a: Yes. Each year a theme is announced

cards.q: What is the IWD theme for 2022
cards.a: **Gender equality today for a sustainable tomorrow**

_data.title: Zero Trust Security
_data.description: Know details of this latest security trend
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What do we mean by **Zero Trust Security**
cards.a: This is a security model that secures an organization by eliminating **implicit trust**

cards.q: Isn't that how most security models are designed
cards.a: Traditional security models operate on the *outdated* assumption that everything inside an organization's network should be implicitly trusted

cards.q: So what, then, is the principle of zero trust security
Is it a new or recent idea
cards.a: Yes. With digital transformation accelerating growth and with remote working and cloud based architectures, it is becoming more imperative to seek validation of users and controlling their access to data at every stage

cards.q: Who coined the term **Zero Trust Security**
cards.a: It was coined in **April 1994** by **Stephen Paul Marsh** in his doctoral *thesis on computer security*

cards.q: What are the important steps in building a zero trust security model
cards.a:
1. Identification of the **critical and valuable data** (digital assets) of an organisation
2. List of **Applications** that need access to the data
3. **Users** of the enterprise who needs access to the applications

cards.q: What are the principles of zero trust models
cards.a:
1. Strong user authentication
2. Machine authentication
3. User Authorisation to applications
4. Application Authorisations to Users
5. Data sharing Authorisations between applications

cards.q: What are implementation considerations to achieve this
cards.a:
1. **Strong authentication** of users
2. **Least access to data** policies
3. **User device** verification
4. **Remove implicit** trust between applications and monitor those that need to have them
5. **Infrastructure related** components like routers, switches, cloud, IoT etc to have validation protocols in place

cards.q: Would this not result in complicated security
cards.a: If done correctly, a Zero Trust architecture results in reduced security complexity and operational overhead

cards.q: What is JIT/JEA related to security
cards.a: It refers to limiting user access with **Just-In-Time** and **Just-Enough-Access** to data

cards.q: Does Zero Trust security prevent security breaches
cards.a: Despite the best attempts to prevent breach it does occur. This occurs due to bad policy implementations and improper technologies adopted to secure the digital assets

cards.q: What is the principle to be adopted in case of security breach
cards.a: The principle adopted is to **reduce blast radius** and to do **segment access**

cards.q: What do we mean by **blast radius** in security
cards.a: A blast radius is a way of measuring the **total impact** of a potential security breach

cards.q: What does **segment access** mean
cards.a: It means control access to an organisations resources with **fine-grained permissions** to manage how users interact with the data
